dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I'm a teacher. There is no word in The English Language -- "Xmas." It's either Merry Christmas... or Happy Holidays. The Workman nods thanks, with faux appreciation, as Mom t away. The Workman shares a look with William, who shrugs that's my Mom.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  4 EXT. MINI-TRACT CONDO COMPLEX -—- DAY 4 This is the new professional-class. It's a mini-condo community. Rows of Spanish-styled three-bedroom houses wi common walls. Move in on one of these homes, the one with Christmas lights. At the door is a furtive 15 year-old Gi She checks her cheek, straightens her hair. She hides something under her coat, and gathers the proper nonchala to enter. Music fades. 5 INT. KITCHEN —- DAY 5 We now hear the dialogue between this lively Mother and h son, as she cooks a pan full of soy-based health-food cut The meal simmers unappetizingly in the pan. Across the ki we see William. He's a great listener, with a calm and cu face that takes everything in.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: - so Livia -

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: -- killed everyone off so her son Tiberius could inherit the throne. (thoughtful pause) Just like Nixon. William nods, intrigued. He has a good disposition. The world of knowledge engages him, and he loves what it brin out in his Mom. There is a small clatter at the front doo as the girl we've just seen enters, barely brushing some She silently curses herself. ELAINE (cont'd) Anita, is that you?

dialogues.speaker: ANITA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hey Mom! I already ate. Mom moves to the living room to greet William's sister. W peers into the next room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's almost to her bedroom down the hall when mom catche her. We now discover ANITA, 16, up-close. She is an allur young Natalie Wood, with a suspicious and sunny smile.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: You sure? I'm making soy cutlets. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca The words "soy cutlets" sends a small shiver through the

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: I'm fine. Already ate. William stands in the doorway now, watching, monitoring, Mom moves closer to his sister. She sees something curiou about her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Wait. You've been kissing.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: (too quickly) No I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: (peering at her lips) Yes... yes, you have...

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: No I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Yes you have. I can tell.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: (boldly) You can't tell. Mom steps closer and examines the lips even more carefull To her, everything is a quest for knowledge.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Not only can I tell, I know who it is. It's Darryl. Anita is stunned silent. She turns slightly to look at he in a hall mirror, searching for clues, implicating hersel immediately. ELAINE (cont'd) And what have you got under your coat? This is the booty Anita didn't want to give up. Mom picks the corner of an album cover now visible under her jacket She withdraws the album. It's Simon and Garfunkel's Booke

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: (busted) It's unfair that we can't listen to Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  our music!

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: (weary of the issue) Honey, it's all about drugs and promiscuous sex.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: Simon and Garfunkel is poetry!

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Yes it's poetry. It's the poetry of drugs and promiscuous sex. Look at the picture on the cover...

dialogues.speaker: BOOKENDS ALBUM COVER
dialogues.text: Mom's fingers at the edges. We examine the insolent faces Richard Avedon's classic album cover. Even Simon and Garf look guilty under her scholarly inspection. ELAINE (cont'd) honey, they're on pot.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: First it was butter, then sugar and white flour. (beat) Bacon. Eggs, bologna, rock and roll, motorcycles. Nearby, William squirms as he watches the gently escalati conversation. Anita glances at her brother. He silently urges her to downshift. She can't. ANITA (cont'd) Then it was celebrating Christmas on a day in September When you knew it wouldn't be "commercialized."

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: That was an experiment. But I understand —

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: What else are you going to ban?

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Honey, you want to rebel against knowledge. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  ELAINE (cont'd) I'm trying to give you the Cliff's Notes on how to live in this world.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: (simple and direct) We're like nobody else I know. These are the words that sting Mom most.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: I'm a teacher. Why can't I teach my own kids? (pats chest) Use me.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: Darryl says you use knowledge to keep me down. He says I'ma "yes" person and you're trying to raise us ina "no" environment!

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: (immediately, can't help it) Well, clearly, "no" is a word Darryl doesn't hear much. Anita gasps. Ever the peacemaker, William weighs in. Near is a poster —- "No More War."

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Mom —-

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Everything I say is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: I can't live here! I hate you! Even William hates you!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I don't hate her.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: (to William) You don't even know the truth! William looks vaguely confused.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Sweetheart, don't be a drama queen. Anita takes a breath and then out of her mouth comes the strangled-sounding words of a kid swearing at her parent the first time.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: Feck you! All of you!

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Hey! Anita runs down the hall to her room. Elaine turns to Wil relating to him more as a fellow parent than a child. ELAINE (cont'd) Well, there it is. Your sister using the "f£" word.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I think she said "feck."

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: (sputtering) What's the difference?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (encouraging) Well. The letter "u"... Shot moves in on the kid, as we hear the opening strains The Moody Blues' "Nights in White Satin."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music continues. Shot moves along a row of very mature-lo male teenagers, examining themselves in the bathroom mirr There's the kid with a very mature-looking moustache, the proudly sporting full-blown hormonal acne (he slaps on so Hai Karate), the guy to whom puberty has already delivere face of an adult, complete with long jutting sideburns... then a blank space at the mirror, as the shot moves down, down to find William. He is so much younger, without a zi sight. Puberty is so very distant on his horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Song continues as we see William's perspective of these m older looking kids. Girls now are visible, and they are e more mature than the boys we've just seen. They flirt and glow, arms trailing across the shoulders of the boys. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca Whispering in each other's ears, none of them looking do It's a troubling experience, to be this close to the allu world of older teenagers... and to be so invisible to the

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0O.S.)
dialogues.text: Are you really in our grade? 9 INT. JUNIOR HIGH LOCKER ROOM —- DAY 9

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (louder) Are you really in our grade? William turns to see tall, adenoidal TIM TOBIN. The most looking kid we've seen yet, he challenges William in a lo theatrical tone. It is a voice right out of Guys and Doll which incidentally is the school play in which Tobin had starred. William answers in a respectful voice. He is desperate for acceptance.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Hey guys! Check it out! William doesn't have any pubes! Others now begin to gather around, examining William. He never been more naked.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: How old are you man?

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: He's not a man, he's a little baby kid. He Doesn't even get zits yet.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: How come you don't have any hair down there?

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: (in loud, funny voice) Where are your pubes?                        ! Their voices echo off the tiled walls. Now everyone is wa the hairless William. He is confused by their meanness.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Where are your pubes? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca All eyes are on him, waiting for a response. The kid's m wheels turn frantically. And from somewhere comes an atti a swagger, and somehow the perfect line arrives from what only be a merciful deity.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (cool, dismissive) I had 'em. JI shaved 'em off. It is a new persona for the kid -- the witty guy. And it Guy #2 cracks up, then others. William's new accuser is suddenly surrounded by the impressed gales of laughter of older boys. Others turn away, on to other things. Tobin s at William, and then also turns away. 10 INT. FAMILY CAR —- DAY 10 William jumps into the backseat of the white Ford Country station wagon, carrying books. ("See ya pubes!") Mom cont driving William and Anita home from school.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: (cheerfully, by rote, to William in back) Put on your seatbelt. I don't want you flying through the windshield. Anita examines her own un-fastened seatbelt, which Mom ha noticed.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: We got our annuals today --—

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: (cheerful, automatic) "Received" your annual.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (looking at his photo) I look so much younger than everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Enjoy it while you can. Camera drifts from Mom to Anita, who can take it no longe

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: Mom. It's time.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  (pleasant, pointed) Can this wait until we get home?

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: Mom, pull over. Tell him the truth. Tell him how old he is. Mom pulls over, and stares straight ahead with deep irrit

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: (as in "be quiet") He knows how old he is.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: The other kids make fun of him because of How young he looks. Nobody includes him. They call him "The Narc" behind his back...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: They do?

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: What's a "Narc?"

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: (bleeding for her brother) A Narcotics Officer!

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Well what's wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (ever the peacemaker) Come on you guys. It's no big deal. I'm 12. It's okay. She skipped me a grade, it's okay. Big deal. I'ma year younger. They're 13, I'm 12 -—- (beat) Aren't I? Their silence is eloquent.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: (confessing, in a rush) I also put you in first grade when you were five and never told you.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (trembling) Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  So... I'm... how old? A heavy quiet. She and his sister ignore him, as they now debate the subject with each other.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: You lied to him! You make such a big deal about the truth and you lied!

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: (that one hurts) He never asked.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: What -- like he's going to ask if he's as old as he thinks he is? Don't you realize, this is going to scar him forever?

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Honey... sweetheart... don't be Cleopatra. We have to be his mother and his Dad.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: You put too much pressure on him!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (apprehensive) How... old...

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: And when he rebels in some strange and odd way, don't blame me.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: am I?

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: (matter of fact) I skipped you an extra grade. You're eleven.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (horrified, voice crackling)

dialogues.speaker: ELEVEN
dialogues.text: He looks at his body, the information affects him physica New sounds come from way down deep inside. Mom now begins speed-rapping, trying to stem the leak. She starts the ca Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you skipped fifth grade. There's too much padding In the grades. I taught elementary school. 5th grade - unnecessary. Nothing happens in the 5th grade. All Teachers know it, no one talks about it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (still in shock) E - leven.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: And you skipped kindergarten because I taught it to you when you were four.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (still horrified, looking at his body) This explains... so much...

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: You've robbed him of an adolescence!

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Adolescence is a marketing tool.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: He's got no "crowd"... no friends...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Okay! Anita reaches out to her brother. With the compassion of saint, she offers this:

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: Honey, I know you were expecting puberty. You're just going to have to shine it on for a while. Deeply embarrassed, William shrinks down in the seat. monitors his face constantly. She is raw and sincere... yes, inspiring:

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Who needs a "crowd?" You're unique. You're two years ahead of everybody. Take those extra years and do what you want. Go to Europe for a year! Take a look around, see what you like! Follow your dream! Mom and Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  You'll still be the youngest lawyer in the country. Your own great grandfather practiced law until he was 93. Your dad was so proud of you. He knew you were a pronominally accelerated child.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: What about me?

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: (heartbroken, can't help herself) You're rebellious and ungrateful of my love.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: Well, somebody's gotta be normal around here!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (blinking, still can't believe it) Eleven. 11 INT. WILLIAM'S BEDROOM -— DAY 11 William finishes the last of many candy bars. A mound of wrappers sit just below the mirror. He examines his face hopefully for zits. Nothing coming. We begin to hear Simo and Garfunkel's "America."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anita stands in the living room. The song continues playi on the stereo.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: I want to play you a song that explains why I'm leaving, and try to listen.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: We can't talk? We have to listen to rock music? 13 EXT. FRONT LAWN -— DAY 13 William watches sadly. Anita's good-looking boyfriend DAR a dead ringer for young Stephen Stills, loads her suitcas into a large turqouise Chevy. The suitcases are adorned w plastic stick-on flowers. All coolness is leaving William life. Mom watches nearby, worried and helpless. (Their ho Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  is more austere, less "fun" than the other front lawns.)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Take good care of her in San Francisco, man. Darryl gives the kid a sub-human look. He's invisible, to young to converse with.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: How can she leave such a loving family? Anita turns and heads towards them. She focuses on Willia placing her hands on his young shoulders. Her face is ver close to him now, as she delivers this sage prediction of future.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: One day you'll be cool. He nods stoically, hopefully. He is utterly lost. She lea forward and whispers in his ear. ANITA (cont'd) Look under your bed. It'll set you free. Anita shakes hands with Mom, and exits. As the car takes

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: She'll be back. In the distance we hear the whoop of her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Maybe not soon... William watches wistfully. He moves away from his mother. She pulls him closer. Shot moves in on his slightly fearf face. 14 INT. DARRYL'S CAR — DAY 14 Anita looks back at the receding American Gothic-image of mother and brother. Sister waves to brother. She feels fo him. Music now shifts to The Who's "Sparks." 15 INT. BEDROOOM —- NIGHT 15 Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  William locks the door. He reaches under his bed. It's a black leatherette travel bag, with tartan design. He unzi the bag -- it's filled with albums. He flips through the amazing, subversive cache of music. Cream's Wheels of Fir the seminal Bob Dylan bootleg Great White Wonder... the R Stones' Get Yer Ya Ya's Out... The Beach Boys' Pet Sounds Abraxas by Santana... Jethro Tull's Stand Up... The Mothe Invention's We're Only In It For The Money... Led Zeppeli Crosby, Stills and Nash... Miles Davis' Bitches Brew... a The Who's Tommy... with a note taped to it.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "Listen to Tommy with a candle burning and you will see your entire future..." The heady effect of all these albums registers, as we see lighting a candle.

dialogues.speaker: NOTEBOOK
dialogues.text: A blue school notebook, with ballpoint pen renderings of names of groups like the Who and Led Zeppelin, complete w carefully drawn thunderbolts. Also, the name LESTER BANGS 16 INT. JOURNALISM CLASS --— DAY 16 William, now 15, sits in class with book, Adventures in Journalism. His hair is shoulder-length. A dedicated teac PATRICIA DEEGAN, walks the aisles. Music continues. 17 EXT. FOOD MACHINES -— DAY 17 William presses the food machine button, pulls an orange a vending container. He still looks younger than most of students... and these days, especially the girls. 18 EXT. LUNCH COURT —- DAY 18 William sits apart from all the others, under a tree. He intently, happily, as he eats the orange. It's a copy of Magazine. Music continues.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOS IN MAGAZINE
dialogues.text: Camera moves across the photos, catching the expressions fashions of the rock heroes of the day. Ian Anderson of J Tull, eyes wide and hair flying as he plays flute. Neil Y enigmatic with perfectly patched Levis. The Southern Rock Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca of The Allman Brothers Band, posing and laughing in fron massive stacks of amps. Marc Bolan of T. Rex, his ringlet backlit by stage lights. David Bowie in skin-tight Japane piece attire, onstage with The Spiders From Mars. Pete To of the Who, slashing windmill-style at his guitar. Drift down to a by-line - by Lester Bangs. 19 EXT. PARKING LOT — DAY 19 William walks through the parking lot after school. Every now congregates around the new arrival of their lives - t own cars. Arms suddenly clap William on the back, friendl faces smile strangely, laughing. He takes a few steps and looks up to see... a school official is hurriedly removin something from the high-school marquee.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH-SCHOOL MARQUEE
dialogues.text: which reads: WILLIAM MILLER IS TOO YOUNG TO DRIVE (OR FUC All are laughing. He laughs with them, and turns as his f goes slack. He shrugs, marches on. 20 EXT. DOWNTOWN SAN DIEGO RADIO STATION —- DAY 20 The song we've been listening to is ripped off the turnta a highly-active man in a red promotional t-shirt proclaim greatness of The Guess Who. He is a ferocious, lumbering, driven presence, and he fills this small radio studio to very brim. This is LESTER BANGS, 25, the rarely-seen God then new art-form —- Rock Journalism. A Disc—jockey with long hair watches helplessly. William views all this thro glass window. He stands on the corner of a downtown side street, halfway up a steep incline. He is the only person the streets this early Saturday morning. Reveal that he i watching a live radio show, audible to us through the sma p.a. speaker overhead.

dialogues.speaker: DISC-JOCKEY
dialogues.text: Quite an honor to have the World's Greatest Rock Critic... and editor of Creem Magazine, back Home in San Diego for a few days -- Lester Bangs.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER BANGS
dialogues.text: What is this hippie station?! Where's Iggy Pop? Don't you have a copy of Raw Power?!

dialogues.speaker: DISC-JOCKEY
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Lester, isn't it a little early for this? Bangs searches for the album -—- vinyl flying everywhere with no regard for album jackets.

dialogues.speaker: BANGS
dialogues.text: Found it!! 21 EXT. RADIO STATION —- DAY 21 William watches intently. Bangs thuds the needle onto a c of Raw Power. We're rewarded with a blast of Iggy and the Stooges' "Search and Destroy." A closer shot on William n watching the whirlwind of anarchy inside. Lester does an Pop impression, acting out a story for the d.j. that we c hear, never noticing the kid soaking in everything from t other side of this double-glass window. 22 EXT. RADIO STATION —- DAY -- LATER 22 Bangs walks with William on this sharply inclined San Die street. It's early, the streets are silent. Bangs is abou fifteen beer pounds overweight. His jeans are loose, his paleness and messy moustache an emblem of the long days a nights spent writing. In there somewhere is a good-lookin guy. His hands are thrust deeply into his pockets, and he takes big sweeping steps.

dialogues.speaker: BANGS
dialogues.text: So you're the one who's been sending me those articles from your school newspaper —

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I've been doing some stuff for a local underground paper, too.

dialogues.speaker: BANGS
dialogues.text: What are you like the star of your school?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: They hate me.

dialogues.speaker: BANGS
dialogues.text: You'll meet them all again on their long journey to the middle. The kid nods, they walk. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  BANGS (cont'd) Well, your writing is damn good. It's just a shame you missed out on rock and roll.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I did?

dialogues.speaker: BANGS
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. It's over.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Over?

dialogues.speaker: BANGS
dialogues.text: Over. You got here just in time for the death rattle, the last gasp, the last grope.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well. At least I'm here for that. Bangs looks at the much smaller kid, shaking his head. It too late for newcomers. But if the kid's age is an issue, doesn't mention it. Like a machine-gun:

dialogues.speaker: BANGS
dialogues.text: What do you type on?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Smith-Corona Galaxis Deluxe.

dialogues.speaker: BANGS
dialogues.text: You like the new Lou Reed?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (automatic) The early stuff. The new stuff, he's trying to be Bowie, he should be himself. I'm not a big Lou man.

dialogues.speaker: BANGS
dialogues.text: Yeah, but if Bowie's doing Lou, and Lou's Doing Bowie, Lou's still doing Lou.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (standing his ground) If you like Lou.

dialogues.speaker: BANGS
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Take drugs?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BANGS
dialogues.text: Smart kid. I used to do speed and sometimes Nyquil and stay up all night writing and writing, like 25 pages of dribble about, you know, the Guess Who, or Coltrane, just to write, you know, with the music blasting...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Me too. The writing part... For a moment, the serious demeanor dissolves and the odde thing happens. Bangs laughs. It's an odd and charming lau the kind a tough guy keeps well-hidden. It surprised the who smiles back. Bangs stops at the corner, and offers a pleasant but very final nod of the head.

dialogues.speaker: BANGS
dialogues.text: Well, alright. It's been nice to meet you. I'll see you around. Keep sending me your stuff.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Okay. See you.

dialogues.speaker: BANGS
dialogues.text: I can't stand here all day talking to my many fans. WIDE SHOT —- SOLITUDE But neither have anywhere to go on this early downtown mo They stand for a beat, hands in pockets, on this deserted street. They are alone together, there's nobody else in s 23 INT. DINER -— DAY 23 William listens intently as Lester eat a sandwich. His fa is an open book filling with words.

dialogues.speaker: BANGS
dialogues.text: -—- so anyway, you're from San Diego and that's good. Because once you go to L.A., you're gonna have friends like crazy but they'll be fake friends, they're gonna try to corrupt you. The Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  publicists! The bands! You got an honest face, they're gonna tell you everything. But you CANNOT make friends with the rock stars. The kid takes out a green collegiate notebook and gesture can I make a note? Bangs nods. BANGS (cont'd) Cannot make friends with the rock stars. (savage bite) That's what's important. If you're a rock journalist, a true journalist -- first you will never get paid much. But you will get free records from the record company. The kid's eyes widen. Bangs, in direct conflict with his writing style, is looking suspiciously like a compassiona softie. BANGS (cont'd) And they'll buy you drinks, you'll meet girls... they'll try to fly you places for free.... offer you drugs... I know. It sounds great. But they are not your friends. These are people who want you to write sanctimonious stories about the genius of the rock stars and they will ruin rock and roll and strangle everything we love about it. Privately, William thrills. We. Our. It all sounds great him. He listens to the grouping of the words, every one o them. He madly scribbles. BANGS (cont'd) They are trying to buy respectability for a form that is gloriously and righteously — The kid leans forward as Lester finds the right word. BANGS (cont'd) - dumb! And you're smart enough to know that. And the day it ceases to be dumb is the day it ceases to be real. Right? And then it will just Become an Industry of Cool.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Industry... of... cool... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's what they want! And it's happening right now. I'm telling you, you're coming along at a very dangerous time for rock and roll. The war is over. They won. 99% of what passes for rock now... SILENCE is much more compelling. It's over. I think you should turn around and go back and be... a lawyer or something... but I can see from your face that you won't. I can pay you thirty-five bucks. Gimme a thousand words on Black Sabbath.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (attempting cool) An assignment.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Yeah. And you should build your reputation on being honest... and unmerciful.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (writing in notebook) Honest... unmerciful...

dialogues.speaker: BANGS
dialogues.text: And if you get into a jam -- call me. I stay up late. Bangs reaches across the table, and William watches as he scribbles his number on the back of the kid's green colle notebook. The notebook has just become valuable. They sit together, listening to the beautiful and compelling silen 24 INT. FAMILY CAR —- NIGHT 24 Mom drives William to the San Diego Sports Arena. She loo out the window at the adrenalized concert-goers. She feel protective not just of her son, but an entire generation. William goes over his questions for Black Sabbath.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Look at this. An entire generation of Cinderellas and there's no slipper coming. William looks out the window at the sign: TONIGHT - SOLD BLACK SABBATH with special guest Stillwater. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can drop me off here.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Black. Sabbath. Just remember - you wanted to be Atticus Finch in To Kill a Mockingbird. The kid doesn't answer. He silently goes over his questio ELAINE (cont'd) As long as I know this is just a hobby, I'll go along with it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: All I have to do is listen. That's what Lester Bangs said.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: (dryly) I'll be waiting right here at eleven ‘o clock sharp. If you get lost, use the family whistle. He unhooks his seatbelt, stuffs his questions into an ora canvas shoulder-bag and exits. Elaine watches her son disappearing into the stony rock-c crowd. It's a windy night. Everything about this image troubles her. She fights with herself, and then uses the whistle immediately. He turns. ELAINE (cont'd) (sweetly, too loud) Don't take drugs!! Fifteen concert-goers turn around instinctively, at the s of a Mother, and then identify William as the object of h concern. All around him, we hear:

dialogues.speaker: HAPPY CONCERT GOERS
dialogues.text: Don't take drugs!! He winces, nods and moves forward. Music echoes from the windows of many other cars. 25 EXT. SAN DIEGO SPORTS ARENA BACKSTAGE RAMP -— NIGHT 25 The kid tromps down the steep incline leading to a small backstage arena door. He rings the buzzer. The door wheez Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca open to reveal the keeper of the San Diego Sports Arena' backstage list. Famous to all those who attempt to enter, this is SCOTTY. He is a wiry, humorless man for whom powerlessness is the theme of his life -- except for thos hours he controls the list. Scotty is only forty but ever about him screams that he's an angry sixty.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm William Miller and I'm here from Creem Magazine to interview the band Black Sabbath. Scotty, immediately suspicious, moves to a nearby podium snaps through three clipboard pages. He moves back to the door and grabs the handle.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Not on the list. He shuts the door with finality. The kid stands silently a moment. He looks over his shoulder, at two chattering Groupies watching his dilemma from the top of the ramp. T look at him sympathetically, but he turns away. William r the buzzer again, withdrawing a copy of Creem from his ba The door opens.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Sir, I'm a journalist, and here's a copy of the magazine. The magazine hangs in mid-air.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: You're not on the list. Go to the top of the ramp with the girls! Slam. William stands there for a moment. Unsure of what t do next, he looks back to the top of the ramp. Rejected b him just moments earlier, the groupies now feign disinter Bracing himself, William rings again. The door opens slow this time. Scotty stands peering at him.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (in a rush) What -happens-after-I-go-to-the-top-of- the-ramp with-the-gi - Slam. Lock. 26 EXT. TOP OF SPORTS ARENA RAMP -—- NIGHT 26 Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca William inches into the realm of the girls at the top of ramp. The wind whips. It's just him, and two Groupies in their evening best. They now pretend to barely notice the young journalist who has been banished to stand with them Chattering excitedly, with sophistication far beyond her years, is ESTRELLA. She sports long unruly black hair. He partner hangs in the shadows, adjusting shoes. Estrella t to the kid with great disinterest.

dialogues.speaker: ESTRELLA
dialogues.text: Who are you with?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (embarrassed to be alive) Me? I'm with myself.

dialogues.speaker: ESTRELLA
dialogues.text: No, who are you with? What band?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I'm here to interview Black Sabbath. (beat) I'm a journalist. I'm not a... you know... Estrella stares at him. Moving into the parking lot light introducing herself, is a luminous girl in a green faux-f trimmed coat. This is PENNY LANE. There is an inviting wa and real interest in the way she asks:

dialogues.speaker: PENNY LANE
dialogues.text: you're not a what?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (enthralled) Oh... I'm just... not a... you know.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY LANE
dialogues.text: Not a "what"?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (charmed) You know. A "groupie." The two girls are deeply insulted by the word.

dialogues.speaker: ESTRELLA
dialogues.text: Ohhh!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Sorry, I - Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We. Are not. "Groupies." Estrella indicates Penny with great reverence.

dialogues.speaker: ESTRELLA
dialogues.text: This is Penny Lane, man. Show some respect.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: -- sorry. Penny steps closer, focusing completely on the kid. Behin her, concert-goers throw a few woo-woos their way. She se not to hear them.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY LANE
dialogues.text: "Groupies" sleep with rock stars because they want to be near someone famous. We are here because of the music. We are Band Aids.

dialogues.speaker: ESTRELLA
dialogues.text: She used to run a school for Band Aids.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY LANE
dialogues.text: We don't have intercourse with these guys. We support the music. We inspire the music. We are here because of the music. William is nodding like a doll in a dashboard window. Listening.

dialogues.speaker: ESTRELLA
dialogues.text: Marc Bolan broke her heart, man. It's famous.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY LANE
dialogues.text: It's a long story. I'm retired now. I'm just visiting friends.

dialogues.speaker: ESTRELLA
dialogues.text: She was the one who changed everything. She said "no more sex, no more exploiting our bodies and hearts... "

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Right. Right. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "J... just blow-jobs, and that's it."

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Okay. Well, see, now I get the difference. Shot drifts off him and picks up, out of the darkness, an breathless girl teetering on tall shoes. She is in the vi of 16. Her black hair is cropped short and died red, just like the cover of Bowie's Aladdin Sane. She is POLEXIA, t voluptuous one, from Riverside.

dialogues.speaker: POLEXIA
dialogues.text: (the usual greeting) It's all happening. It's all happening.

dialogues.speaker: ESTRELLA
dialogues.text: Polexia!! Did you tell Sabbath we were going to be here?

dialogues.speaker: POLEXIA
dialogues.text: I talked to Dick with Stillwater, I talked with Sabbath. They're all dying to see us. It's all happening.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY LANE
dialogues.text: This is our journalist friend. Journalist Friend, meet Estrella Starr, and Polexia Aphrodisia. And you are --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: William. Silent beat. His name lands like a thud.

dialogues.speaker: POLEXIA
dialogues.text: Here comes Sabbath!

dialogues.speaker: ESTRELLA
dialogues.text: Ozzy!!! Tony!!! It's us!! A long black limo with darkened windows swishes past, bee twice. The metal backstage gate rises and the limo rolls inside. And then silence again. The girls do not discuss being rebuffed. ESTRELLA (cont'd) I think I saw Sapphire in there.

dialogues.speaker: POLEXIA
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  (can't hold it in any longer) Okay. I was with Ian Hunter all night at Rodney's Last night. Wanna see his spoo? I saved it in a baggie. She opens her purse and shows the girls something inside. William edges away.

dialogues.speaker: ESTRELLA
dialogues.text: (peering into purse) I'm really happy he's doing so well.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (regarding what's in purse) Yeah. I know he's such a talented guy. I mean, look at him. Who deserves it more?

dialogues.speaker: POLEXIA
dialogues.text: (looking in purse) Nobody -- he's so sweet.

dialogues.speaker: ESTRELLA
dialogues.text: (with compassion) Don't you just root for him, you know. To go that little distance between good and great?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Wait. That's not his. I would know his. A very odd look on his face, William now cranes for a dis look. What's in that purse?

dialogues.speaker: BAM
dialogues.text: Out steps SAPPHIRE, 19, a tall girl with taller platforms eye-makeup. Her accent is Texan, with odd traces of Engli In one hand is a half-drained bottle of champagne. In the a fistful of backstage passes.

dialogues.speaker: SAPPHIRE
dialogues.text: Does anybody remember laugh-tah? (as they turn) Come and GET 'EM! The girls scream and happily head down the ramp to Sapphi Penny looks back and grabs William with a well-placed arm around his. He joins the clacking sea of legs moving down ramp. Sapphire slaps passes on the girls. As Scotty (The Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca Keeper of the Backstage List) watches, Penny now slips W forward for a pass.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Oh no. Not this one -—-

dialogues.speaker: SAPPHIRE
dialogues.text: (off William) Who brought Opie? The kid looks over his shoulder. Who's Opie?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: He's with us.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: (hand blocking William) He wasn't with you.

dialogues.speaker: SAPPHIRE
dialogues.text: (to Scotty) Are you going to turn this into a Thing?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: All of you can wait outside! Top of the ramp!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I don't want to cause a Thing. I'll wait.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (privately, to William) I'll go take care of this. Sadly, they leave him behind. The thundering arena sound the collecting crowd, the p.a. system blasting Yes' "Roundabout"... purposeful roadies carrying guitar cases. the glimpse of backstage rock and roll... everything he w to be a part of is on the other side of this door. And th it shuts. He stands alone. At the top of the ramp, a tour bus unloads. It reads -—- STILLWATER TOUR 73. Moving loudly out of the bus is the o band. This is Stillwater. Four road-weary band members, a their road manager. Voices booming. RUSSELL HAMMOND, 27, presses the buzzer with the nose of guitar-case. It's obvious from moment one. This is the st of the band, the charismatic one. He's tired. They're lat Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca William recognizes him instantly, as the guitarist stret The buzzer goes unanswered. The kid is invisible to him, the others now arrive behind Russell. Tour/band manager DICK ROSWELL, 27, follows, loudly bangi the steel door. He has the flaxen-haired look of a former hippie, but he carries the emblem of a real pro -—- the n silver Halliburton briefcase covered with backstage passe His direction is always - forward.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Let us in, we're Stillwater! We're on the show!! William is surrounded by them now. They stand together un single lightbulb, familiar faces, a live-action album cov BEBE the singer, his shiny black hair hanging in sheets a head. ED VALLENCOURT the quiet drummer, his long arms han limply at his sides. His is a face made for the backgroun TURNER the compact bass-player. Dick now kicks at the doo his foot, as William produces a copy of Creem Magazine.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (to Dick) Hi, I'm a journalist. I write for Creem Magazine. Once again, the magazine hangs there. He can't give it aw

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: The enemy! A rock writer!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (struggling forward) I'd like to interview you or someone from the band.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: (busy, running behind) I'm sorry but could you please fuck off? William blinks a little, takes it in stride. Russell size him up, moving in the background.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay. I could do that.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: You guys never listened to our records. You're all just frustrated musicians. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Do you know what your magazine SAID about us? What was it - "the singer's incessant cater walling distracts From an assault with no clear purpose."

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (in background) That was Rolling Stone.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Okay. Fuck off anyway. We play for fans, not critics. Stung, William shrugs. It's been a terrible night, but at least thrillingly so.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Russell. Jeff. Ed. Larry. (can't help it) I really love your band. I think the song "Fever Dog" is a big step forward for you guys. I think you guys producing it yourselves, instead of Glyn Johns, was the right thing to do. And the guitar sound was incendiary. (gestures with fist) Way to go. He turns and leaves, beginning his long trek back up the Russell looks at the others. That kind of love is hard to give up.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (good humored, yelling) Well don't stop there.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Yeah, come back here!! Keep going! They wave him back, as the backstage door opens again. Th kid moves back down the ramp. They herd him in with them, through the door. Scotty quickly spots the kid and square off. Russell notes the kid's swirling emotional state, shoves forward.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Not this one.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  He's with us.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: He's not with you. He's not with them. He's not on the list. He's not coming in. And this is my arena. And furthermore — Russel craves the confrontation and moves forward closer Scotty. SCOTTY (cont'd) —- have a good time tonight. Welcome to San Diego. 27 INT. BACKSTAGE HALLWAY -—- NIGHT 27 The band moves quickly down the hallway, with William mov to keep up. A young and grizzled red-haired roadie, RED D catches them on the way. The band swarms around him.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Red Dog!

dialogues.speaker: RED DOG
dialogues.text: We're playing here tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (aside, to the kid) This is Red Dog, the Allman Brothers Band's number one roadie. Russel clamps an arm around Red Dog's neck.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: How're the guys?

dialogues.speaker: RED DOG
dialogues.text: Havin a ball, man. When we have a party, we have an Allman Brothers Band party. Everybody boogies. Everybody gets off. It's family, man. We all got These now. (flashes new mushroom tattoo on forearm) We'll see you guys in Boston, right? (specifically to Russell) Dicky and Gregg send you their love. Camera catches flash of envy on the face of Jeff Bebe, as Stillwater sweeps forward into a small dressing room. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  28 INT. DRESSING ROOM --— NIGHT 28 Dressing room activity swirls around him, as William simp listens. He holds a small microphone. His stoic look give little of the full body rush he's experiencing. As the ot band members drift across frame, Russell Hammond, a true roll believer, speaks as he straps on his guitar and gets for the show. To the kid, every word is reckless gem.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: and it's okay, because rock and roll is a LIFESTYLE... anda way of thinking and it's not about money and "popularity!"

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Some money would be nice. Jeff sprays some shaving cream into his palm, and rubs it his scalp - poor man's mousse.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: - but it's a voice that says here I am... and FUCK YOU if you can't understand me. Russell smooths the strings of his guitar with a small cl from his guitar case. The kid notices all these close-up details of rock. RUSSELL (cont'd) And one of those people is gonna save the world and that means that ROCK AND ROLL CAN SAVE THE WORLD -- all of us together. The kid's eyes dance. He checks to make sure he's getting recording. He listens intently.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: And the chicks are great.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: But we didn't do it for that! We are here because we needed to fuckin be here, not just 'cause we needed to away from Troy, Michigan, WHICH WE DID... but what it all comes down to is that thing. The Indefinable Thing, when people catch something from your music, the thing you put into it. I'm Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  talking about... what am I talking about?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (elegantly) The buzz?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: THE BUZZ! And the chicks, the whatever, is an off-shoot of THE BUZZ. And like -- you saying you liked "Fever Dog?" That is the fucking buzz, man. All we get are these fucking old-ass interviewers who don't understand, don't LISTEN, don't appreciate why we are here, which is the fuckin' BUZZ. William nods, holds his microphone steady. Russell tunes guitar, ripping through unamplified guitar licks as he sp Jeff hustles to reclaim his own connection to the intervi

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: The next album will be even better. More texture.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: But... it's not what you put in, is it? It's what you leave out. Listen to... listen to Marvin Gaye... Russell's face grows rapturous as he discusses this piece music. RUSSELL (cont'd) A song like "What's Going On." That single "woo" at the end of the second verse — you know that woo - that single "woo."

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (proudly) I know that, "woo."

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (he does it) That's what you remember. The silly things, the little things... there's only one, and it makes the song. It's what you leave out. That's rock and roll. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca William nods, says nothing, keeps the microphone pointed Activity surrounds him.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (impressed) We used to talk more about this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Okay. See, this is maybe the most honest we've ever been in an interview because you know our music. You're the first press guy we've made friends with. We don't normally talk like this to them. And you're supposed to be The Enemy! What are you - 18?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: There you go. Still young enough to be honest.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: (walkie talkie crackling) Ten minutes 'till showtime, anyone who isn't in the band -- out! Russell takes a last swig of beer. A roadie whisks his gu away. DICK (cont'd) All this luggage is going to L.A.! William is swept out in the chaos of the pre-show ritual, past the pile of luggage by the door. It's a colorful hea suitcases, featuring colorful laminated band tags, each w number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William sits on the backstage steps, writing feverishly i notebook. Behind him, two steps higher, Penny Lane scoots into place.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY LANE
dialogues.text: I found you a pass.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (amped, distracted) Thanks. I got in with Stillwater. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  (as he writes) The guitarist, Russel Hammond, he just thoroughly opened up. He is by far the best and most honest interview I've ever done. (she nods) I've only done two, but you know. He's number one.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY LANE
dialogues.text: You're learning. They're much more fun on the way up. William nods, still scribbling. She eases down into place the step next to him. Her proximity cause him to look at her, his eyebrows rising. She smooths them down with two fingers. PENNY LANE (cont'd) How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Eighteen.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY LANE
dialogues.text: Me too. (beat) How old are we really?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Seventeen.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY LANE
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Actually I'm 16.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY LANE
dialogues.text: Me too. Isn't it funny? The truth just sounds Different.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (confesses) I'm 15.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY LANE
dialogues.text: You want to know how old I really am?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (immediately) Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  No. She looks upstairs, soaking in the sound of another band up. Music is her religion. WILLIAM (cont'd) How did you get started in all this?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY LANE
dialogues.text: It's a long story.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (quick study) Right. Right.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY LANE
dialogues.text: We live in the same city. We should be friends. She takes his backstage pass form his shirt and puts it o thigh - the cooler location. Nearby, the dressing room do opens, and the Stillwater exits. Excitement level rises a they mass in the hallway with instruments. We hear the am voice of Russell growing nearer.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: The Enemy! He approaches, as William stands. Penny watches, hanging of Russell's eyesight. Standing in the supercharged hallway, the kid is anxious introduce his new friends.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Russell, this is Penny Lane.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY LANE
dialogues.text: (stepping into view) Pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Penny Lane? Like the song, right?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY LANE
dialogues.text: Have we met?

dialogues.speaker: THEY SHAKE
dialogues.text: And do not let go, for too long. There is history in thei shake. Their eyes tell all. Shot takes us to William, who Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca puts two and two together. It isn't hard. They clearly k each other. Well.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well, I guess you've... you've met.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Penny Lane! God's gift to rock and roll!! You're back! (privately) Marc Bolan. Please. Other band members pass, adjusting clothes for show time, waiting in the hallway... and now singing the Beatles son "Penny Lane."

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Come on, let's go. (noting kid's shyness) Both of you. 30 INT. BACKSTAGE -— NIGHT 30 House lights go down. Cheers rise. Dick's flashlight danc on the ground just in front of them, guiding their way in dark to the stage steps.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: — get in the huddle. Russell pulls William into the band's huddle.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT LOOKING UP AT THEM
dialogues.text: Their band ritual, psyching together, arms on each other' shoulders in a circle. They sing a dew lines of the class "Train Kept A-Rollin'" (or "Go See Cal" from the Cal Wort ad) They all touch feet, and then break, heading for the Russell directs Penny to his side of the stage. The kid f Plugging in, still in darkness, Russell hits a practice c thwack. He steps on effects pedal. Applause. (Adlib onsta private patter, between members, goading each other -- th no audience ever hears) Twenty feet away, Dick prepares t address the crowd from the darkened stage. It is his favo moment of the evening, the highlight of his job.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: From Troy, Michigan. Please welcome -—- (importantly) Stillwater. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca Light hits the stage, and the band launches into their o song, "If You Say Nothing." Audience response is strong. Shot lingers on the face of William as he soaks in the mo undeniably exciting moment of any concert, the first thir seconds. Jeff the singer grabs the microphone and launches into so vocal pyrotechnics. Russell looks over to Penny and Willi at stage right, grinning, pretending to trip on his cord, elegant show-off move of a musician who is now where he belongs... before seriously stepping forward for the firs guitar lead of the night. The kid looks over to see Penny watching Russell. 31 EXT. BACKSTAGE -—- NIGHT -- LATER 31 Cases are shut and rolled toward the trucks. Stillwater h for their bus. Jeff the singer says goodbye to Estrella S like a sailor leaving port. Russell lingers behind, sayin goodbye to William, loading his own equipment. Black Sabb passes with entourage, heading to the stage.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (privately) So. You want to come up to L.A., we'll be at the "Riot House" all week.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: "The Riot House?"

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: The Continental Hyatt House! It's on Sunset Strip.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (attempting cool) Right. Right. All the while, just over the kid's shoulder, Russell scan backstage crowd of hangers-on. Looking perhaps for Penny

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Let's blow this burg!

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (exiting) Well tell your friend Miss Penny Lane to Call Me. Tell her "It ain't California without her. We want her around like last summer." Say it like that. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (returns, whispers) Oh, I'm under the name - Harry Houdini.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (exiting, to William) The Enemy!! Yeah!! Come to L.A., we'll take some more. Russell joins Jeff, exiting and laughing. A good show is in the air.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Later Jeff! See you, Dick. Larry. Ed. (and now the roadies) Mick, Gregg, Red Dog, Scully, Frosty, Estrella, The Wheel!

dialogues.speaker: ROADIES DICK
dialogues.text: Laterrrr! We'll see you down the line. William is deliriously happy, hands upraised. He turns to Penny.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (calming him) Hey. Hey. Be cool.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You just missed Russell! He says he's at the "Riot House" all week and to call him. He's under the name Harry Houdini. Do you know about the "Riot House?"

dialogues.speaker: PENNY LANE
dialogues.text: I think I've heard of it.

They were so outside, they're inside, and insiders never even knew it, because they're outsiders and they are inside a place outsiders will never be. And why are we even talking about it? dialogues.text: Whoa! (laughing) I need three more beers and my guitar before I can answer that question. Let's take a walk. 69 EXT. They stand for moment, unheard by the others, and regard the living port twenty yards in front of them. The off-limits after-hours pool area has been overtaken by the Stillwater tour membe Jeff Bebe sits in a chair nearby. Dick laughs at a joke. Always the life of the party, Penny Lane dispenses stolen from a maid cart. And she is the first to slip into the p for some after-hours, against-the-rules swimming. Effortl she turns a collection of people into a party. They regar her, well out of earshot of the others.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: For a minute I thought you were actually a real journalist... which is... you know, it's great. (beat) Shut that thing off, and I'll tell you the truth. William shuts his tape recorder off.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: It's off.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Look. I trust you. I'm going to lay this right on you. Just make us look cool.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I will quote you warmly and accurately.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: That's what I'm worried about. See - some of us have girlfriends back home. Some of us have wives. And... some of the people you meet on the road are really amazing people... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca They both watch Penny Lane, sparkling, fresh from the po She places hotel furniture into the shallow end and invit all, even other curious hotel guests, to join them in the RUSSELL (cont'd) Like you. And some of the things that happen are good for just a few people to know about - as opposed to, say, a million people. Dawn is breaking for William.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Ohhhh. Oh. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: You know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Right. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: See, you're dangerous. Most people are just waiting to talk, but you listen.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Right. Right.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: So your question you asked me. I think about It every fucking night. The "business." I hate it! (quietly) I grew up with these guys, okay? I can't play all that I can play, I'm past these musicians, do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: The more popular we get, the more I can't walk on them, the bigger their houses get, the more pressure... you forget, man. You forget what it was like to be real, to be a fan. You can hear it in a lot of bands who've been successful - it doesn't sound like music anymore. It sounds like... like lifestyle maintenance. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  (suddenly confessional) I used to be able to hear the sounds of the world. Everything, to me, used to sound like music. Everything. Now I don't hear it. You know what I'm trying to say?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (ruefully) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Man, it feels good to say this stuff out loud. But what am I doing? I'm telling secrets to the one guy you don't tell secrets to.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (feeling included) No, that's okay. We'll do the interview tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: This is good. So there's the "friend" and then there's the "interview guy."

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: So tonight it's "friend".... and when we wake up tomorrow —- "interview guy." We'll figure it out as we go, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hey - for whatever it's worth - you guys are really good. Russell laughs at the kid's easy naivete. He hands his gu to the kid, and joins the party. William watches, part of crowd... somehow feeling a little compromised. He doesn't care. Penny gestures for him to join them. 70 EXT. SUN STADIUM — AFTERNOON 70 William interviews Larry in the seats of the empty arena. stage, Ed soundchecks his drums.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: How would you describe your role in Stillwater? What is the chemical that Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  you add to the chemistry?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I'm the bass-player.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (pressing for some poetry) Right. And when you take that away... what would be missing? Stylistically? What chemical?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (not getting it) The bass? Larry doesn't give him much. 71 EXT. SUN STADIUM —- NIGHT 71 It's raining. The pre-show huddle breaks up, William a pa of them. Penny Lane adjusts Larry's look. She takes the s from around his neck and ties it around his leg. He looks instantly better. William watches in the darkness as Dick takes the microphone. The best part of his day has arrive In his important voice:

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Good evening Phoenix. (applause) From Troy, Michigan. Please welcome, Stillwater. Lights come up, as the band launches into "Fever Dog." Je begins singing. Russell reaches to adjust the microphone a back-up vocal and is hit with something unexpected. A sharp electrical shock. It's just a slight pop in the loud din of music, but with moment something is clearly wrong. Russell holds onto the microphone stand with a surprised look, conducting high-v for two seconds and then he snaps his hand off the metal. face is white, he takes off his guitar and walks off-stag collapsing a couple steps later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick is waving wildly for the band to board the bus, whic been pulled up into the backstage area. He guides a saggi Russell, assisted by Penny Lane, into the bus. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in, get in!! William boards the bus, as the extremely agitated PROMOTE arrives to confront Dick.

dialogues.speaker: PROMOTER
dialogues.text: Are you the manager of this band?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: That, and more. Get in!

dialogues.speaker: PROMOTER
dialogues.text: You didn't even play a full set! Dick whirls and unleashes an anger we've not yet seen, ge with the silver briefcase that does not leave his hand.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Your shoddy stage set-up almost killed our guitarist!

dialogues.speaker: PROMOTER
dialogues.text: You trashed the dressing room —- you didn't play your thirty-five minutes. You didn't fulfill your contract —

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Everybody in! Get in the bus!

dialogues.speaker: PROMOTER
dialogues.text: I'll report you to every promoter in the country! I'm gonna talk to Frank Barcelona!

dialogues.speaker: PROMOTER
dialogues.text: I hope you have a good lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: I AM A LAWYER
dialogues.text: He swings into the bus, as the bus revs.

dialogues.speaker: LOCK THE GATE ON 'EM
dialogues.text: 73 INT. BUS -—- NIGHT 73 Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca Russell sits, pale, next to Penny at the front of the bu examines his singed hand, shaking it a little to emphasiz positivity of her words.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Don't worry. It's happened to all the greats. Thank God you didn't hold the mike stand with both hands, you'd still be holding it. This is a good thing. It's a good, good, good thing. William sits nearby, watching Russell, making notes out o sight of others. The ever-wary Jeff, unseen by William, c to see that he's writing in his notebook. Dick swings into the seat across from Russell. The bus do shuts, as the promoter is still yelling. Doris is slow to gain speed, as Estrella appears, running alongside. She knocks on the window next to William.

dialogues.speaker: ESTRELLA
dialogues.text: I forgot to tell you! Your mom says to call home immediately. She says she knows what's going on! (receding) See you guys in Topeka! I'll catch a ride with Sabbath! William nods with embarrassment, waves to her, as the bus toward the now closing gate.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: (casually, to Russell) Wanna buy a gate? Before Russell can answer - BASH. Doris barrels through t steel-gate, snapping it like a chopstick to great cheers this bus. DICK (cont'd) You just bought a gate. (to the bus) C'mon Doris!! Get us out of town!! The bus struggles up a slight incline, everybody rooting Doris, as she eases out of the parking lot and onto a thoroughfare.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What did it feel like to be Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  electrocuted?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: It burns. It feels like a dose of lead shooting through your body... and then you see God, and he says, "How bad do you want to be legendary?" And god damnit. I let go. (shaky grin as all laugh warmly) Rock and roll. Jeff watches this charisma with thinly veiled envy. The k scribbles in his notebook. We hear Led Zeppelin's "That's Way." 74 INT. BUS —- EARLY MORNING 74 Song continues. Almost everybody is asleep. William takes the camera and snaps a Polaroid of a sleeping Penny. She up.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Give that to me. She grabs for it, they have a brief play-fight. He grabs other Polaroids from her pocket. He hustles to the back o the bus, pockets the photo, and settles down to watch the passing landscapes. She chases him down the aisle. Music continues as she sits down next to him. Out the window, a long-distance running team of Girls keeps pace with the b for a bit. They wave. Penny watches them over sunglasses, waves briefly to the real world. PENNY (cont'd) (breathing heavy, owning the world) When we go to Morocco, I think we should wear completely different clothes, and be completely different people.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What will our names be? She snaps a Polaroid of a nearby sleeping Silent Ed, pock the Polaroid. She regards Russell up ahead, also sleeping Her attention has already wandered from Morocco.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: What do you think of Russell? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like him.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You're coming to Cleveland, right?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Cleveland, Ohio? Oh no no no. I gotta get my interview with Russell before Greenville. And you've got to help me. Okay? Friends... remember? Penny is still watching Russell.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You should give him a break. There are real problems in the band. off the record. Gravely noting the word "problems", the kid joins Penny i watching Russell, who is splayed haphazardly, sleeping restlessly up ahead.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What problems?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Okay. I got it. I think your name should be Spencer, and mine will be Jane.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I can't keep up with you.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: No one can.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What's your real name? She looks at him briefly. She puts her arm around him. It intoxicating, but he doesn't quite know how to act. With free hand, she gestures with a hanger. As they regard Rus sleeping nearby:

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Here's the thing about Russell. He's my last project. I only do this for a very few people. And I think we should do it together —- he is almost great. We've got to take him there. You and Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  me — we can do it. Deal? Because the other guys are good - but he could be great. He's my last project. He looks at her. She imitates his face back to him. PENNY (cont'd) It's all happening. 715 INT. TOPEKA ARENA BACKSTAGE —-— NIGHT 715 William sits interviewing Silent Ed by some equipment cas

dialogues.text: What do you love about music? Ed looks at him thoughtfully. It is an eloquent moment. H thinks. He shrugs. The kid tumbles with more questions. These interviews are not going well. 76 INT. BATHROOM — NIGHT 76 William, looking concerned over the state of his intervie walks into the backstage bathroom. He makes a few surrept notes in his notebook before noticing that Jeff is standi there, clearly just finishing a quick hit of cocaine offe by a Local Hanger-On. Seeing the kid, he immediately hide the coke spoon.

dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hey. William pretends he sees nothing as he turns to the urina and shot stays on Jeff, who looks a little high and a lit worried. 77 INT. BACKSTAGE PAY PHONE — NIGHT 77 William is on the pay phone with his Mother. The show boo in the background.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I know. I know. I know. (beat) I know. Mom. Mom... Mom. 78 INT. STAGE — NIGHT 718 Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Stillwater on-stage. A great show. Russell on fire. 719 INT. BACKSTAGE PAY PHONE — NIGHT 719 William on the phone. Estrella leans on him, fixing her s

dialogues.text: Right now -—- Topeka. Then Greenville. Then home. He winces slightly, holds the phone away from his ear for moment. WILLIAM (cont'd) I'm sorry I didn't call yesterday! It's not like you can just carry a phone around with you. 80 INT. ELAINE'S SCHOOL OFFICE --— AFTERNOON 80 Mom sits in her school office, a miniature version of her - a fortress in which she is surrounded by books. The sun going down. She can't resist a sentimental moment.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: I guess I just miss you, and I don't understand why I've driven both my kids so far away from me. By all practical rules don't I get you for three more years? He is touched by her vulnerability, more visible now than as music continues in b.g. ELAINE (cont'd) Was I not fun? 81 INT. BACKSTAGE PAY PHONE -—- NIGHT 81 William has his finger in his ear. The din if Stillwater' set now blots out all other noise. It is not the time to this question.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I missed the last thing you said. Mom takes a pause.

dialogues.speaker: I LOVE YOU.
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Penny now enters, watching.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: (angry, louder)

dialogues.speaker: I MISS YOU AND I LOVE YOU
dialogues.text: William now notices Penny standing nearby, picking at a s from a paper dish. Looking at her, he lets loose with wha believes is a private confession.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I LOVE you!! Penny smiles knowingly, collecting his affection like ano backstage pass, and turns away. Camera stays on William. is suddenly and deeply embarrassed. He's just told her th he loves her and she knows it. He hangs up, traumatized. 82 INT. TOPEKA DRESSING ROOM —- NIGHT 82 Russell's hair is slicked with sweat from a show just fin He is shirtless with a towel around his shoulders. Luggag for the next city is stacked by the door.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Fire away. I'm ready. I'm on the "You" Train. Take me there. The kid plugs in his microphone. Russell listens as he sp his first question.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Do you have to be depressed to write a sad song? Do you have to be in love to write a love song? Is a song better if it really happened to you? Like, "If You Say Nothing"... where did you write that and how did it come about? Russell admires the many questions. Says nothing. He look at his hand, thinks.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: When did you get so professional? In the background, Penny Lane irons Silent Ed's shirt. Grinning, she cuffs his shoulder. To the shirtless silent drummer, waiting for his shirt. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm almost done with my shirt. Ed watches her appreciatively, drumming silently on a rub pad. Penny kisses Russell, who swings her onto his lap. I the corner, Jeff watches them all with a vague feeling of underappreciated. And now Dick enters with a large cardbo box.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Russell, your dad showed up again. And on a lighter note. (importantly) Gentlemen. Your first t-shirts have arrived. There is an immediate buzz in the room, as Dick yanks ope box filled with new white t-shirts. He untangles the firs shirt, and displays it proudly. A silent beat as all exam their first t-shirt. Faces fall. Ed stops drumming. There been a mistake. It is a fuzzy band photo with the group n emblazoned below. Only Russell, who stand out front, is c in and emphasized on the shirt. He turns away, making a n Jeff stares at the t-shirt. He's just about in tears. The a long silence and then... Ed resumes drumming on the rub DICK (cont'd) It's the record company's mistake. And they will pay. Shirts gone, band happy. He drops the offending shirt into the trash, as if it wer contaminated, and exits with the box. William watches as two men, Russell and Jeff, move to opposite sides of the Russell puts on a shirt, so does Jeff. The vibe is thick. Russel turns to see Jeff staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Can we just skip the vibe and go straight to us laughing about this?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Yeah. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (trying for a joke) Because I can see by your face - you want to get into this — Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.text: How can you tell? I'm just one of the out-of-focus guys.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Here we go. William watches as Russell fishes the t-shirt out of the RUSSELL (cont'd) Here. Take it. You LOVE this shirt - it lets you say everything you want to say.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Well, it speaks pretty loudly to me.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: It's a t-shirt. Russell turns away.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I'm always gonna tell you the truth.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Are you doing coke again?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. All the time. The kid looks down. JEFF (cont'd) This is big stuff, man. From the very beginning -- we said -- I'm the front man and you're the guitarist with mystique. That's the dynamic we agreed on -- Page, Plant... Mick, Keith. But somehow it's all turning around. We have got to control what's happening to us. There's a responsibility here -

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Excuse me, but didn't we all get into this to avoid responsibility?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Forgive me. (continuing, on shirt) But this is the slow-moving train of Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  compromise that will kill us. Russell makes a disgusted noise. Penny Lane exits discree looking back at William. JEFF (cont'd) I can't say anymore with a writer here.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: You can trust him, you can say whatever you want.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (eyes suddenly moist) I works as hard or harder than anybody on that stage. You know what I do - I connect. I get people off. I look for the guy who isn't getting off, and I make him get off. (beat) Actually, that you can print. (continues to Russell) And yet, why do I always end up feeling like I'm a joke to you? I feel nothing but love for you. We're a family. He looks at the t-shirt and starts to cry. Embarrassed, h grows angrier. JEFF (cont'd) You want to pretend this isn't going to be a very big band. Well it is. You call yourself a leader of this band, but your direction allowed the t-shirt, when you allowed Dick to manage us, ‘cause he's your friend... don't you see? The t-shirt is everything. It's everything.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Is it my turn? Because I think we should, for once, say what we really mean.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Oh, this is the part where you quit -

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (stiffening) Right. I'm so predictable.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  No I gotta tell the truth -- I want you to like me. But sometimes I feel like you collect people who love you and then very skillfully... you make them feel bad that they're not good enough for you.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Stick to singing, brother, 'cause you ain't gonna make it as a shrink.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Deal with it! And let me just say what nobody Else wants to say to you —

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Your looks have become a problem. 82A EXT. BACKSTAGE — NIGHT 82A Russell walks swiftly past a happy silver-haired man, who court with beer in hand. He dresses too young for his age late fifties. He is DAD.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Son!

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (dutifully) Hello Harry. Dad introduces a woman much younger, who eyes Russell hun

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: He got all the good genes, huh? Meet Deirdre. We're getting married in July. 83 EXT. ARENA -— NIGHT 83 Russell walks fast outside the arena. William hustles to up. The two men walk in long silent strides in the cold n air, beyond the backstage area. Fans begin to recognize a follow at a discreet distance.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You okay? You alright? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Russell doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (resolute, wound up) From here on out, I'm only interested in what's real. The kid nods. They walk. RUSSELL (cont'd) Real feelings. Real people. That's all I'm interested in... From here on out. What is REAL? You're real.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Thanks. A wave of warmth comes over Russell.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: You know, you know all about us and I don't know shit about you. (struggling to be personal) What's your... your family like? Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well, my dad died of a heart attack and my sister believes that my Mom is so intense that she might have contributed to it. Plus -

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (immediately) Okay, that's good. That's enough.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: It's good to talk about it. Really good. Russel now sees some hero worship in the kid's face, and makes him nervous. WILLIAM (cont'd) Hey, man, maybe we should go back.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: If they want me, they can find me. William turns and sees nobody following but fans. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
