dialogues.text: So listen. I have to go home tomorrow. I know this is a bad time to finish our interview.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Hey, man, you know what? Write whatever you want. I trust you. A big square Chevy van slows down. A CONCERT-GOER hands h head out the window.

dialogues.speaker: CONCERT-GOER
dialogues.text: (battle-cry) Wooooco0o0000!!! You're Russel from Stillwater!!

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: On my better days, yes. I am "Woooooo, Russell from Stillwater!"

dialogues.speaker: CONCERT-GOER
dialogues.text: Wanna go to a party at my friend Aaron's house?! I know you're a big rock star, but do you want to hang with some people looking to have a good time? Russel regards the van full of kids. More fans crowding around. The kid behind the wheel unknowingly says the mag words. CONCERT-GOER (cont'd) We're just real Topeka people, man. He has said the magic word. A84 EXT. AARON'S PARTY -— NIGHT A84 Russell arrives at the party in the rural outskirts of To William nearby. 84 INT. AARON'S HOUSE -—- NIGHT 84 William watches as Russell slugs from a Jack Daniels bott They sit in the bedroom of a mindblown fan, 17 year-old A He has long frizzy brown hair, tied in a spray behind him Many from the neighborhood are now pouring into the home.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (eyes glowing) You. Aaron. Are what it's all about. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  You are real. Your room is real. Your friends are real. You are more important than... than... all the silly machinery. And you know it! In eleven years it's gonna be 1984, man. Think about that!

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Wanna see me feed a mouse to my snake?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: Can I have your belt?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Take it! Russel whips off his belt, gives it to the fan. A joint g by, headed for Russell. William intercepts it and passes on. RUSSELL (cont'd) Aaron? Where's your bathroom? I want to live here. I want to eat your food, and live in your city and fuckin rock like I used to. I want to learn everything there is to know about your city and your town. And your way of being real. (stunning realization) I used to be you.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Down the hall by the washing machine.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: The bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Okay. Good to know. Russell rises and squeezes past fans and heads down the h

dialogues.text: William follows Russell protectively. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.text: wOOCOOO00! ! A QUIET GIRL, 14, turns and watches Russell pass. We ling on her face for just a moment, full of wonder.

dialogues.text: We should probably head back sometime. Russell ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Topeka. Check it out. Russell enters the bathroom. William stands guard. With a finger outstretched from each hand, he lectures the fans in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Please don't give him any more acid.

dialogues.text: William watches as a wobbly Russell Hammond, in sunglasse now, goes through Aaron's record collection. He places th albums over his face, like masks.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Faces. Stones. Sa-weet Baby James!! None of these people are gonna be around in twenty years! Plastic begets plastic!! Black plastic. Partygoers are strangely fascinated by the rock star in t living room.

dialogues.text: William waits anxiously to use the phone, keeping an eye Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca Russell. Russell is now strangely twisting/dancing with girls in the living room, as more cars arrive outside.

dialogues.text: He's here right now! Go ahead and put it Out over the radio, tell people to bring food And beer and chicks. We're at Rural Route # 4 -

I got him!! He's okay... I've been Looking after him. He's on acid, though. I can't Really tell. How do you know when it's "kicked in?" 88 EXT. AARON'S BACKYARD -— NIGHT 88 Russel stands on the jutting corner of the house rooftop. The unlit, unheated greenish family pool beckons to him b It's kicked in.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (bellowing to the heavens)

dialogues.speaker: I AM A GOLDEN GOD

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hey Russell —

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Don't jump, okay?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: And you can tell Rolling Stone Magazine my last words were - He spreads his arms, and tries to think of last words. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  RUSSELL (cont'd) -- I'm on drugs!! The kids cheer. William looks around, remains cool. Yells upward in the cold night air.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I think we should work on those last words.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Critic!!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No, I'm not —

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Okay I got it. I got it. I got it. I got it. This is better. Last words (spreads his arms, his greatest realization)

dialogues.speaker: I DIG MUSIC
dialogues.text: It gets a skimpy reaction from the partygoers. RUSSELL (cont'd) (immediately) I'm on drugs!! They applaud again.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Just come on down!!

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (matter-of-fact) Okay. He jumps from the roof into the cold, algaed water below. sinks immediately. One kid jumps in, then another, then m Everybody wants to save Russell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's getting lighter. Cars line the street. And now, fina turning the corner, is Doris the Bus. 90 INT. KITCHEN -— MORNING 90 Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  William watches the effects of personal charisma. Wet partygoers surround Russell, bottle of Jack Daniels still hand, wrapped in towels. Now a bond has passes between th all of them. Algae drips from the corner of Russell's fac and neck.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Thanks for saving my life. I won't hold it against you. Twenty different kids thank him for the opportunity. ("Gl to do it," "Right on," "Damn straight.")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Door opens. Dick enters. Finding the guitarist in the kit he clicks into time-tested road-managerial maintenance. E Russell out of his towel, slipping his own jacket around from Russell's hands.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: (privately) They've been crying for you like a bunch of whimpering pussies ——

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (woozy) The band is over. This is my family now.

dialogues.speaker: OTHERS
dialogues.text: Right on. He's staying with us.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: (soothing) Definitely. It's all over. We'll just ride on to Greenville, listen to some great music, finish the tour, and leave those ungrateful fools behind. And then we'll come back here, where you'll live.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: I know what you're doing... and I like it. (noticing William) Look at him. He's taking notes with his eyes. (beat, to Dick) How do we know he's not a cop? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca William laughs painfully, as Russell moves in, eyes flar with sudden paranoia. RUSSELL (cont'd) He could be selling information!

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: (to Russell) Easy. He's your Guardian Angel. Russell turns away. William shrugs with style, but his lingering look is filled with hurt. Dick guides Russell t the door, grabbing the kid and talking very directly to h they move. DICK (cont'd) Don't worry. He only means half of what he says.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Which half?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Good question.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (very direct) I have a lot more. Just help me get my interview so I can go home from Greenville. I have to go home. (pulls him back) I have to go home.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Hey. You saved the tour. That's good enough for now. Frustrated but feeling important, William hands him some Russell's wet clothes. William deftly retrieves Russell's and smoothly plucks the guitarist's sunglasses from the partygoer who also wears his belt. They move to the door pack. We hear the beginning of Elton John's "Tiny Dancer. Dick faces the crowd and addresses them in his "important stage voice. DICK (cont'd) Ladies and Gentlemen, the evening is over! We hope you've enjoyed yourselves, and we'll See you again in 1974!! Good evening!! Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca William gives Russell his sunglasses to face the sunligh Russell stumbles out of the house to great cheers. The Qu Girl breaks free to catch Russell on the way out.

dialogues.speaker: QUIET GIRL
dialogues.text: I'll never forget you. Dick pats William's arm one more time -- good work. They Aaron's house as legends. 92 INT. TOUR BUS —- MORNING - 5 AM 92 "Tiny Dancer" continues on the bus stereo. Russell sits u front, swathed in a large robe, alone and silent. The oth have given him a wide berth. He feels silly, and they kno it, and he hates that they know it, which makes him feel foolish. He sits silently. William watches him from four rows back, next to Penny. She kisses the top of his foreh a hero's welcome. He yawns. The song's vocal begins. Ther only more silence. Then, after a beat, we hear a voice or two, fighting the quiet and singing along. Then others... waking up... joining in. Then Jeff. Russell hears them an starts to sing along too, louder now, without turning aro It's a voice everyone wants to hear. Like it or not, this his family.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: 93 EXT. HIGHWAY —- DAY 93 Passing signs announce Greenville, North Carolina. 94 INT. LESTER BANGS BEDROOM — DAY 94 Lester on the phone. He is paler than ever, in a room clo with vinyl, happily listening to the MC5 in the backgroun

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 95 INT. WILLIAM'S HOTEL ROOM — DAY 95 It's a small wooden-walled hotel room in Greenville. Pole tries on clothes. William barely notices as he talks to L on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Rolling Stone is calling me. I don't have my key interview. I don't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER BANGS
dialogues.text: (pacing, assembling thoughts with his hands) You're flipping out. That's good. Alright. This is how you blow their minds. He'll ask you - this is Ben Fong-Torres, right? -— he'll ask you how the story's going. Here's what you do - let's fry his mind. Tell him "it's a think piece about a mid-level band struggling with their own limitations in the harsh face of stardom." Ha ha!! This is fun! William scrambles to make notes.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (madly copying) think... piece...

dialogues.speaker: WRITING
dialogues.text: Longhand small script on yellow legal tablets. 96 INT. HOTEL BATHROOM -—- NIGHT 96 William sits in the tub, without water. It's his makeshif office, he's surrounded with scraps of notepaper. He writ savagely, and now, savagely throws it away. 97 INT. HOTEL BEDROOM --— NIGHT 97 In the bedroom, Sapphire, Polexia and Penny watch The Mid Special. Sapphire looks at a room service menu.

dialogues.speaker: SAPPHIRE
dialogues.text: It says the food is hearty and adventurous.

dialogues.speaker: POLEXIA
dialogues.text: (yawns ) Greenville. I'm bored. Penny yawns too, it's catchy, and rises to visit the bath POLEXIA (cont'd) Hey let's deflower the kid. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Now Sapphire yawns, looks in her purse.

dialogues.speaker: SAPPHIRE
dialogues.text: Who his the quaaludes from me? 98 INT. HOTEL BATHROOM —- NIGHT 98 Penny enters to see William writing in the tub. She sits the toilet to pee. Flustered:

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Wait. I'll leave. He gets up, knocking his carefully organized notes onto t floor. He is brimming with things to say. More than he is even able to communicate. WILLIAM (cont'd) You know, I think this is going backwards for me.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Backwards?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (flustered) I don't know. I just thought we could hang out, maybe do some stuff back home, regular stuff, get to know each other better... and then I'd see you pee. I mean, that's the way I usually do it.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You're one of us. It's no big deal.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I'm not one of you.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Oh! If you go to Cleveland, Bowie's going to be there at Swingo's, the greatest hotel in America. I'll introduce you to him, and his security guy Dennis. William stops at the door.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Don't you have any regular friends? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Famous people are just more interesting. He looks at her. Even sitting on the can, she's elegant a totally focused on him.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (carefully) Well, I would be worried that they were using me. And not that anybody's using you, but — She swoons a little, touched and moved.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Boy, if this was the real world and some guy talked to me like that -

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Let me finish. (continuing) I'm not famous.... but you could always use me. If anything happens. And I would never use you. Even if I got famous. So you know, you always have that from me... in the real world. If you ever have to go back there, for anything. She looks at him curiously, as the door blasts open. Sapp and Polexia head for William.

dialogues.speaker: SAPPHIRE
dialogues.text: Your time has come.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Did he call? (realizes their intention) What are you -- stop it -- we're talking here.

dialogues.speaker: SAPPHIRE
dialogues.text: Pants him. Opie must die. They swarm him, dragging him kicking into the bedroom. 99 INT. HOTEL BEDROOM --— NIGHT 99 Steely Dan, looking pale and somehow snappy, perform "Do Again" on The Midnight Special. The girls force William o Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca the bed, and envelope him. Their sexuality is fun, untro Shot moves past bodies crossing frame, onto William's fac

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Across room, sitting and watching.

dialogues.speaker: SAPPHIRE
dialogues.text: Just relax. Take a vacation from yourself. Leave this to professionals. Estrella and Polexia kiss each other playfully. William l confused. Across the room, Penny laughs, turns up the TV, blows him a kiss. Penny's eyes. Across the room. His eyes. His sexual awakening may be downtime amusement for them, to him it's an embarrassingly intense moment he shares on with Penny Lane -- across the room. She turns away, smili disappears into the next room.

dialogues.speaker: ON STEELY DAN
dialogues.text: On the television.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: 99A INT. BEDROOM — NIGHT - TWENTY MINUTES LATER —- HANDHE Post-sex pajama party. Sapphire, Estrella, and Polexia gi about their first rock and roll conquests. Penny is consp by her absence. William is under the sheets, listening, f different, now a man and somehow one of the girls too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William is awake. Sunlight floods in from the corners of window-shades. He is surrounded by the fallen cavalry of night before... Sapphire and Polexia. The phone rings, an Sapphire instantly snaps it up, still asleep. Lost in her dreams, she offers the sexiest hello ever.

dialogues.speaker: SAPPHIRE
dialogues.text: (half-English accent) Hello. Hi, Ben-Fong-Torres from Rolling Stone. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  William snatches the phone.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (lowers voice) Hello. 101 INT. BEN FONG-TORRES' KITCHEN --— SATURDAY MORNING 10 Ben Fong-Torres is up bright and early.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Hello William, this is your editor at -- He offers the name of the magazine with a swirl that impl high-level importance. BEN (cont'd) Rolling Stone. How's the story? INT. GREENVILLE HOTEL ROOM —- CONTINUOUS William snaps into his very professional tone of equally importance.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I'm getting good stuff out here.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Sounds like it. Next to him, Polexia yawns herself awake.

dialogues.speaker: POLEXIA
dialogues.text: Man, I need some — He clamps a hand over her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (jocular but tough) Now listen. Get it together. We're both professionals, I don't have to tell you this. You're not out there to join the party -- we already have one Hunter Thompson. You're out there to interview and Report. You got me? This isn't Creem Magazine, it's Rolling Stone. We need this story in four days. Now I want to know how it's shaping up. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a think-piece about a mid-level band grappling with their limitations in the face of the harsh glare of success.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (pause) I like what we're saying. Let me try and get you a thousand more words. It's in consideration for the cover, but don't tell the band.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (conflicted) Crazy. The kid hangs up, now shouldering even more pressure. He unclamps Polexia's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: POLEXIA
dialogues.text: — coffee.

dialogues.speaker: SAPPHIRE
dialogues.text: Me too. Greenville is so boring. (to William) Any other city in the world and you'd still be a virgin.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I'm going out to find Russell.

dialogues.speaker: SAPPHIRE
dialogues.text: Will you take the laundry?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (to the girls) What am I to you? Tell me right now! What. Am. I. To. You. 102 INT. HOTEL HALLWAY —- DAY 102 Circles have sprouted up under William's eyes. The orange strapped over his shoulder, he lugs a huge bag of laundry consults room list. A variety of noises and smells drift the band rooms. He sees Room Service arrive at Dick's doo and it's Estrella who opens the door. (Dick in the background.) She smiles sweetly to William -- good mornin as the door shuts.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Houdini... Houdini... He arrives at Russell's door. Two exclamation points have been Sharpie-markered to the words Do Not Disturb on the is gaffer-taped to his door. He looks through the crack, the bottom of the door. Carefully and politely, he knocks Instantly:

dialogues.speaker: GO AWAY
dialogues.text: Pissed, the kid flips off the door. He sits down on a cha directly across from the room. Push in on William, who is more pent-up than ever. He tries hard not to cry, taking gulps of air as a maid cart swishes past, revealing... he failed. He cries.

dialogues.speaker: FADE UP FROM DARKNESS
dialogues.text: A super-energized Russell Hammond looks into William's sl face. William's eyes open. His own sleepy face is evident Russell's sunglasses. The bag of laundry is still at his RUSSELL (cont'd) We'll do the interview in Cleveland!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No. I can't. You've got to help me. I have to go home.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Come on man, we'll have more time there. Don't be tense!! He begins rubbing the kid's shoulders. He's waking up. Th Penny, also rubbing his shoulders. It is degrading... and somehow cool too.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (to Penny) You said you'd help me.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (massaging) Come to Cleveland.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (massaging, hypnotically) Come to Cleveland... Come to Cleveland... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't!!

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Can we help it if we like having you around! William is a bundle of nerves and exhaustion now. Embarra and frustrated. RUSSELL (cont'd) Cleveland, my man. You can't miss out on the Rock Mecca of the midwest — you're with us. It's all happening!

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Rock and roll!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (weary) Rock and roll. We hear David Bowie's live version of "Waiting for the Ma 103 INT. HOTEL ROOM —- DAY 103 They sit together, hair askew, in sunglasses, resting aga the headboard. Carefully, Russell identifies his thoughts

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: I feel... like his parents. Penny runs a worried hand through her hair.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: I wonder how that happened.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You ever notice that all our sentences begin with "I?"

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: I hadn't, no.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: "Cause we should work on that. He looks at her, plays the guitar a little. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  104 EXT. HIGHWAY — NIGHT 104 Night. Doris rocks toward Cleveland on a muggy summer nig The windows of passing houses offer rich Edward Hopper gl of lives and people William will never meet. 105 INT. WILLIAM'S BUS BUNK — NIGHT 105 William watches from his bus bunk at the back, head on el Looking up, he sees the rhythmic motion of bodies on the mattress above him, as music continues. William gets up, nods hello to the Roadie and his Date on bunk above. He moves down the aisle... to the seats near front. A sleeping Russell sits upright, hugging his guita Penny asleep next to him, Polaroid in her hand of... Russ sleeping. The kid moves on. He sits with the Bus Driver, whose CB crackles with chatter from other tour buses head Cleveland. ON THE FIRST SIGN — LATE NIGHT Cleveland signs. Music rises. Heads pop awake.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Cleveland!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a slow-moving shark, Doris pulls into empty downtown Cleveland. The streets are empty. They pass the Agoura Ballroom, where a man with a long stick arranges the lett Stillwater on the marquee. Applause in the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell and band enter like warriors, in a pack. William with the heavy bags in hand and over his shoulder. Here, the middle of the midwest, is an explosive rock mecca, ju promised. The feeling of belonging invades all those in t lobby. Fans and other touring rockers mingle together. Outside in the real world, everyone else is going to work

dialogues.speaker: FAN
dialogues.text: It's Bowie! The lobby ignites, as William stands near Penny and Russe Bowie races from a limousine through the lobby and into t elevators. He is shrouded by a jacket. Just the top of hi electric red hair travels the lobby, as he's hustled by s Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca man Dennis in the elevator. And out of the chaos comes.. 108 INT. HOTEL ROOM — DAY 108 Jeff Bebe and Polexia smash against the wall of the Swing hotel room, making love. 109 INT. HOTEL ROOM — DAY 109 Russell and Penny Lane smash against their own wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick squats at the front of the stage, and talks to a few in the front row of this crowd. 110 INT. BACKSTAGE CLEVELAND PAY PHONE — NIGHT 110 A wild Cleveland crowd in the building. The cities on thi tour are getting bigger, and so are the audiences. And th is a whiff of business now too. Men in satin tour jackets some Disc-jockey types cruise the backstage. A Hysterical is led screaming to the nearby medic room. Few even react it's Cleveland - as the shot finds William, tired and yaw on the backstage pay phone. He is absolutely ready for th worst.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hi Mom. I'm in Cleveland. He listens stoically. Larry and Ed watch nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. LIVING ROOM -—- NIGHT Moms sits in silence. WILLIAM (cont'd) (rehearsed) I'm fine! I'm fine! I'm flying back on Monday Morning. I'll only miss one test. I'll make it up. Russell listens in, holding his guitar, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Tell her you're a slave to the groove - you can't help it!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  (covers phone) No. Russell grabs the phone, talks to the silent mother on th other end.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Hi Mom! It's Russell Hammond, I play guitar in Stillwater! It's my fault. How does it feel to be the mother of the future of rock journalism? (beat) Hello? Silence. Penny passes and stands near William, smoothing pass. They watch a new pack of groupies prowl the road-cr They are more glam, more trashy and less selective. They insolently at Penny Lane. This is the future. RUSSELL (cont'd) You've got a great kid -- nothing to worry about! We're taking care of him! And you should come to a show sometime! Join the Circus!

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Listen to me. Your charm does not work on me. I'm onto you. Of course you like him.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: He worships you people and that's fine with you, as long as he helps make you rich.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (a nerve is struck) Rich? I don't think so -

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Listen to me. He's a smart, good- hearted, 15 year-old kid, with infinite potential. Russel looks over at the kid, eyes narrowing as he proces the truth. He's 15? ELAINE (cont'd) Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  This is not some apron-wearing mother you're talking to. I know about your Valhalla of Decadence, and I shouldn't have let him go. He is not ready for your world of compromised values, and diminished brain cells that you throw away like confetti. Am I speaking clearly to you?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: If you break his spirit, harm him in any way, keep him from his chosen profession -- which is law, Something you may not value but I do -- you will meet the voice on the other end of this telephone. And it will not be pretty. Do we understand each other?

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Yes... yes...

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: (always the teacher) I didn't ask for this role, but I'll play it. Now go do your best. "Be bold and mighty forces will come to your aide!" Goethe said that. It's not too late for you to be a person of substance. Get my son home safely, I'm glad we spoke. She hangs up. Russell hangs up, oddly affected and shook

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Some people get her. Some don't. Russell is still recovering. William feels embarrassed by mother, once again.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE HUDDLE 111
dialogues.text: William with the band. He yawns, as the band breaks. Clev awaits. We follow Dick, who guides the band onto the stag platform, still in darkness. Already, stomping and applau is mounting. Russell turns to William before taking the s

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Your Mom kind of freaked me out. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She means well. Still rattled, he takes the stage. We see the unbridled enthusiasm of the faces on the front row. A wave of cigar lighters stretch out before them.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: (importantly) From Troy, Michigan... Russell thwacks a couple chords. Audience thunders. He tu to other members, feeling chills. It's in these moments t everything else disappears. They bow and wave, still in darkness... each member seems to have his own fans. Dick all this play out before finally adding... DICK (cont'd) Would you please welcome to Cleveland... More applause. This is very very very very fun. DICK (cont'd) Stillwater. Lights come up. A full blast of audience love hits them r in the face, as they begin "Fever Dog." The band charges headlong into their set, as various fans are squeezed up of the crowd and onto the stage.

dialogues.speaker: HANDHELD ON RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Who is in the middle of playing, as he smoothly whips off guitar, and uses the instrument to send a Frenetic fan ba into the crowd. He slips back under the strap, laughing. More stage climbers spring up where that fan came from, a Russell now watches as Jeff Bebe dodges a fan and comes o to Russell to lean on him. Russell turns to share the mom with Penny, dancing with arms in the air at the side of t stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William in the dressing room, eyes red with exhaustion, f interviewing Russell. He holds the mike stoically.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: So when you play a great show like tonight... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Dick enters with great urgency.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Okay. I need everybody's attention. The kid shuts his eyes. He knew this would happen. DICK (cont'd) Alright, well, the rumors are true. The record company has sent a big-time manager here to try and talk you into replacing me. His name is Dennis Hope. I know you've all heard of him. He's got all the big bands. He's right outside. He wants five minutes with you right now. I think we gotta do it.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (pissed) Then bring him in. William shuts off his tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (arrogant) Bring him in! We'll send him out on a rail!

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (to William) We'll finish on the way to Boston. You can fly home from Boston. William nods, exhausted, as Dick opens the door. In walks small general of a man in a baseball t-shirt, well-trimme beard and bowl cut. He holds the super-new Halliburton briefcase. He is DENNIS HOPE, 25. A man from the midwest, with a vision of the future of rock and roll. Already in head are all the things that will come to pass. Higher ti prices. Merchandising deals. Greater distribution and accounting of album sales. He shrugs hello to the band.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS HOPE
dialogues.text: (completely unthreatening) Hi.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: We already have a manager. He's been with us from the beginning. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca Hope appreciates the lack of small talk. He strides the with the joyful enthusiasm of a kid who wants to build a Russell watches, dismissive, holding his guitar.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS HOPE
dialogues.text: Respectfully. We all have our roots. I believe in bands holding onto their roots. But those roots need to be augmented. I'm gonna tell you the truth —- I may enrage some and enthrall others. I don't really give a fuck. Your manager here needs a manager. Example. If you hadn't run out on the contract in Phoenix, you could have sued over Russell's hand... but you left, negating the contract, forfeiting the deposit, and you effectively traveled a long way to pay that promoter... to electrocute you. Russell looks at his hand. DENNIS HOPE (cont'd) We can all work together. Your damages have put you way into the hole for this tour. Right now you owe the record company more than you've got. But your record's selling, there's money to be made. So I've brought a plane in, we can add more shows to make-up the difference. Respectfully.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (immediately) We travel by bus.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Doris is the soul of this band! That bus has been our home since we were the Jeff Bebe Band. Dick watches his loyal band with admiration.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: Hey man -- it's travel on a pogo stick if I thought we'd make more money. You can play more dates with a plane... 112A INT. CLEVELAND ARENA — NIGHT — SAME TIME 112A Penny Lane stands on stage facing the empty arena. The ro Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca have packed up and moved on. She is alone in the poetic trash filled structure that was just hours ago filled wit people. (Behavior to come)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band meeting continues.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (passionate) Hey man, it's not about the money! It's about Playing music, and turning people on! The band agrees.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS HOPE
dialogues.text: (delicately) Yes, of course. Clearly. Respectfully. But on the distasteful subject of money. Just know. You're making it -- right now -- and it's all -—- He gestures to infinity. DENNIS HOPE (cont'd) -- out there. I'm just talking about bringing it -—- Bringing his hand together in a fist, he returns it, clos his heart. DENNIS HOPE (cont'd) —- back here. The band looks at Dick, who manages not to be speechless.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: But why should we pay you for something we can do ourselves?

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS HOPE
dialogues.text: (immediately) Do you know how to keep from getting charged for the ice below the floorboards of Chicago Stadium? Do you know how to do a headlining tour, do you Claire Rothman at the L.A. Forum? Do you know Bobbi Cowan, Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Lisa Robinson, Jim Ladd, Frank Barcelona? (look around, amazed) This is Cleveland. Where's Kid Leo?? (basics) Do you know how you get a record not pressed but played? Do you know? I didn't invent the rainy day, man. I just own the best umbrella. He laughs. It's fun. Band members are now listening, curi spellbound. DENNIS HOPE (cont'd) Because as much as you may believe that it will last forever, it does not last forever... your biggest fan right now soon they're going to go to college, gonna wanna buy clothes, spend that money some other way, and you know what? (the final insult) They'll tape your record from a friend's copy. Russell stops fingering his guitar. Shot moves across the faces of the band members. Pain. DENNIS HOPE (cont'd) You've got to take what you can, when you can, while you can. And you've got to do it now. That's what the big boys do. The band squirms, but listens. DENNIS HOPE (cont'd) Because if you think Mick Jagger will still be out there trying to be a rock star at age fifty, you're sadly sadly mistaken. Now he's reaching them. Their slackened roar-weary faces back at the young dynamo.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: (flustered) Yeah, well... we'll think about what you said.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS HOPE
dialogues.text: (casually) No no. You don't understand. I'll Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  think about it. I'm not auditioning. I came here to decide whether I want to represent you. So I'll stand outside for a moment, and think about whether I want to stay. He leaves the room with a pleasant shrug. Stunned silence William watches their body language. No one wants to talk first. Their faces read as -- who was that guy, and how c we talk him into staying? 113 INT. PLANE -— DAY 113 William watches as the band stands inside the new plane. Hope looks on.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: This is not us. This is too much. He looks around for support. Grim nodding faces. RUSSELL (cont'd) (impressed at seat) This is too much. William watches as Russell reclines. Russell grabs Penny, she falls into the seat next to him. We hear the loud onc sound of the plane in flight, as Dennis cooly asks for Pe seat.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS HOPE
dialogues.text: Do you mind? 114 EXT. PRIVATE AIRPORT —- DAY 114 Doris the bus stays behind in the parking lot, abandoned a field. The new plane lifts off in the background, as th bus sits alone, as if crying steel tears. Bus Banner read simply: CLEVELAND. Reprise ending of Whole Lotta Love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls sit on the jumper seats at the back of the plan with William. 116 INT. BOSTON HOTEL ROOM HALLWAY -—— DAY 116 William trudges the hallway with tape-recorder and notebo trolling for Russell. He passes Boston travelogue posters the walls. A few room doors are open, he looks for any si of the guitarist. William veers into Dick's room, where a Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca poker game full of Roadies is in progress. The room is t with exotic smoke. They are a bunch of road-hardened snob smoking cigars and other items, famous to themselves, lis not to rock and roll... but Sarah Vaughn.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Anyone seen Russell?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: The Enemy! Door widens to reveal Russell.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Hey! Welcome to the Road Crew Poker Party. This game's been going of for two years.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: That's Mick - he's with The Who. That's John - with J. Geils. And that's Richard with the Eagles... and you know The Wheel.

dialogues.speaker: THE WHEEL
dialogues.text: Hey. Grumbling roadies continue playing. Like an old pro, the turns down a Cola-can hash-pipe. This hand is down to Dic and a roadie named REG from Humble Pie.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Side proposition. For fifty dollars and a case of Heineken, I will put into the pot... three Lovely Ladies, Including the famous Penny Lane... the Band-Aids, who need to exit our tour before New York...

dialogues.speaker: REG
dialogues.text: It's a deal. Show 'em. Dick lays down three tens. Reg lays down three Kings. Dic loses.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Three Lovely Ladies... now in the custody of Humble Pie.

dialogues.speaker: REG
dialogues.text: Alright, so we owe you fifty dollars Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  and a case of Heineken. Embarrassed, Russell notices the kids face. He leans over and speaks confidentially to him.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Look. Nobody's feelings are getting hurt here. She already knows Leslie's coming To New York tomorrow. They all understand. This is the Circus. Everybody's trying not to go home. Nobody's saying goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No, I got it.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: These are the Rules that come with every electric Guitar and every amplifier. They're not just written anywhere. Rock and roll, brother. No attachments. No boundaries. But the kid feels bad, and Russell knows it. RUSSELL (cont'd) Quit looking at me like that. 116A INT. HALLWAY —- AFTERNOON 116A The kid is still stuck on the road. He is in hell now. Wearily, with deep circles under his eyes, he shuts his e for a moment. Another band is moving through.

dialogues.speaker: SABBATH ROADIE
dialogues.text: Keep this hallway clear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William and Penny sit on opposite ends of a blue locker-r bench. It's a small dressing room, crowded with roadies, guitars and men in stages of half-dress. Piles of luggage headed for New York sit by the door. The door suddenly op and Dick arrives with champagne and a cake decorated with sparkler. It is placed in Penny's lap. It reads: Unforget Penny... Age Unknown. Boston, 1973. They gather now as th cake sits before a surprised and enchanted Penny Lane.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Happy Birthday from us. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca William watches her face as she reads the message on the It hasn't sunk in yet. Russell produces a piece of hotel stationery. He reads a

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: So Penny our friend has gained another year. But long ago, she threw it in gear. She rocked the south The East and West. Could you please get off this endless tour Where we're Black Sabbath's fucking special guest? Laughter. RUSSELL (cont'd) She says she's retired Though we've heard that before. She chose us... And in Penny Lane we trust She is a fan of this band. Much more so than us. William watches her face. Still enchanted, she hands out of the cake.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS HOPE
dialogues.text: (to the point) Sorry the plane isn't bigger. It hits her. She looks at William for a clue. His truthfu face does not look away. Now she knows. She turns to the others -- the plane isn't bigger? Shot moves in on Penny she blinks just a little, cutting into the cake, still mu for everybody, covering it all with a layer of sweet gidd laughter. Shot comes to rest behind her, her head turning connect with band members. Each of them look away, nobody maintaining eye contact with her except the one she now d look at. William. She blows out the candles, vamping Mari Monroe-style, and sucks off the frosting seductively, to Russell watches, as we push in on Penny. She notices all luggage is gone, only her two cases remain by the door. 118 EXT. CONCORD PAVILLION BACKSTAGE -— EARLY MORNING 118 William exits a backstage Portosan. Penny catches him by grilling area where catering is preparing for the outdoor Their laminated passes swing from around their necks. Thu in the distance, Stillwater plays for a cheering outdoor The sound of summer insects in the air. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it wasn't a birthday party, it was a farewell. William doesn't answer. He looks at her, blowing some hai out of her face. PENNY (cont'd) You think you can fool me. I read you. I know what you're thinking.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (touched) You're worried about me and Russell.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yeah. I gotta work on that.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You're so sweet. God -- if there was more of you in him...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Don't tell me this stuff. I want to like him.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (concerned for him) Did you miss your test or something? He shakes his head. It's so beyond a test. PENNY (cont'd) I know I'm not on the plane, and I'm not going on some other band's bus. I mean, I could go with the Sabbath road crew, but that would be pathetic. The girls are all going with Humble Pie. If you could find out from Russell --

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (quietly) Penny -

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (a decision) Forget it. I'm flying to New York Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  myself. I have a bunch of partial tickets. I know his ex-wife, current girlfriend's going to be there — William's eyebrows rise. She examines his face for clues.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: —- I'm not sure that's a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (overlapping) What? What are you saying? What do you know? Did Russell say something?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I don't know anything.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I know he wants me there. He gave me a cake. He wrote me that sweet poem.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (loud) Wake up! Don't go to New York!

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: What are you telling me? She looks so achingly beautiful to him.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Because you're not who you said you were! I thought you were retired!

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You're right. I'm not who I said I was. I'm just like you. I love music, so this is my family. Some people like tractors, and they hang out with tractor people. What's the worst that could happen if I go to New York? (little girl) "I get my little heart broken?"

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh no. Never you! You eat people alive! She tears some leaves off a tree. He looks at her, unable formulate a response. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (accusatory) I'm sorry I told you so much. You have some way of making everybody tell you all their secrets.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: That's a good one. Tell me too much and make it my fault. He continues walking, she follows. They have ventured out the backstage area, onto adjoining Boston farmland. The s booms in the background.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Come on. You've seen what's happened. Russell and I fell in love. How much, I don't know... but this is the first time I've fallen for someone, really fallen... since Iggy, and I'm not happy about it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (beat) You slept with Iggy Pop!? She says nothing. WILLIAM (cont'd) (sputtering) Why don't you just tell me now, who else -- so when I go to the record store, I know who to be jealous of. Because right now, it's looking like the whole store! He's upset. She stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (teasing, defiant) You'll remember me forever. I was there when you lost your virginity.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (upset at the memory) So was Steely Dan! It was a crowded room. She laughs, can't help it. Then:

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  You make me laugh. I think I'm gonna cry.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (continuing) I thought we were going to Morocco! There's no Morocco. There's never been a Morocco. There's not even a Penny Lane. I don'teven know your real name.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: If I ever met a guy in the real world, who looked at me the way you just looked at me...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: When and where does the real world occur? I am really... confused here. Fuck! All these Rules And all these sayings... and nicknames...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You know -- you're too sweet for rock and roll.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Where do you get off... where do you get "sweet?" I'm not sweet. I'm dark and mysterious and pissed-off and I could be very dangerous to all of you... I'm not sweet, and you should know that about me! I am The Enemy.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You're not any of those things and that's what I love about you. William stands there in disbelief, unable to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You fall in love to keep from falling in love.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I don't want to go home!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well, I have to go home. And you never helped me. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I did.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: That disc-jockey in Arizona got a better interview than me... and he was asleep. He starts walking back to the stage. She follows. They ar two very young kids thrashed by the seas of rock and roll His frustration increases. She just doesn't get it. Appla in b.g. She grabs his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Look. You should be happy for me. You don't know what he says to me in private. Maybe it is love. As much as it can be with someone who —-

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (blurts) -- sold you to Humble Pie for fifty dollars and a case of beer? I was there! He is instantly sorry. Her world privately crumbles, but tries to remain stoic and carefree.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: What kind of beer? 119 INT. HUMBLE PIE CREW TRUCK -—- DAY 119 Sapphire, Polexia, and Estrella bump along to the music a the road. They strain to maintain dignity in these decide third-class surroundings. There's only one small blurry w

dialogues.text: Who did this to us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Then don't come home. Don't do this to me. If you're going to miss graduation, don't come home. She hangs up. 121 INT. PRODUCTION OFFICE -—- NIGHT 121 Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  William on the phone. Speechless. 122 INT. COLLEGE CLASSROOM —— DAY 122 Elaine faces her Humanities class. She stands in an amphitheater-style, inner-city college classroom, decorat with colorful unorthodox artifacts from her home. These e city college students listen to her. But she cannot conti There is a thundering upset inside her.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I can't concentrate. (beat, confesses, unhinged) Rock stars kidnaped my son. 123 INT. BAND PLANE —- DAY 123 Music. Russell and band bounces down in NYC. Up ahead, Manhattan loo beautiful and scary.

dialogues.text: "New York. Just like I pictured it...

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: " skyscrapers and everything."

dialogues.text: (to William) We showed you America. We did everything but get you laid. Beat. They look at each other curiously. How much does th other guy know? 125 EXT. ST. They hold collecto sleeves covering albums to be autographed, and fresh magi markers in hand. William in tow crawls out of the limo la Dick goes to work, pulling luggage from the trunk. dialogues.text: I'm from the Church of Lenny. We bow to his will and all that it represents — The King of the King of Kings.

dialogues.text: Make it out to - ?

dialogues.text: To Lenny. Russell nods -- of course. He signs, as Dick approaches w a well-placed word in his right ear.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: She's here. William turns, expecting to see Penny. Instead we see the long-limbed, athletic, pretty and collegiate LESLIE. She holds a Nikon camera, and snaps their picture.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Leslie!

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Your room is completely stocked, far away from any noisy ice machines, elevators or maid quarters. The air-— conditioning is already on. And here is your security key -- by the way, you look stunning.

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE
dialogues.text: (taking treatment for granted) ThanksI'llseeyoulater. Nearby, the young journalist studies the tour's subtle sh in welcoming Leslie. Dick's New York side is almost milit

dialogues.text: Bags in five! Cars leave for the party at six! William studies Leslie, everyone saying hello to her, eve knowing the subtext. Nobody saying a word. William pulls heavy bag out of the back of the limousine. The bag breaks, and the contents spill out onto the New Y sidewalk. Bars of soap, ashtrays, hotel keys, crumpled pa the contraband t-shirt, "Do Not Disturb" signs, notes, to and thick telephone books from every city. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  DICK (cont'd) You know. There are lighter souvenirs.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Well -- I kept thinking I was going home the next day --

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I did too. Fifteen years ago. All help him with his spilled souvenirs. Russell shares a private look with the kid. Nearby Leslie greets other ban members.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Ric! It's Super Zeppelin fan Ric Nunez.

dialogues.speaker: RIC
dialogues.text: (whispers) It's all happening. Zeppelin is at the Plaza. So's four other bands. They're partying up there right now. Sapphire, and Miss Penny Lane too... She wants you to call her. (William reacts) They're all staying under the name Emily Rugburn. William takes in the information, while regarding Ric's n custom shirt, which features the words to Zeppelin's "The Song."

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (exiting with Leslie) After the party. I'11l come to your room —- I promise. We'll talk. This is Leslie, by the way. Leslie, this is our wayward friend from Rolling Stone. The Enemy. They shake, she smiles randomly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William checks in.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  William Miller? Sir, you have an urgent call from a Mr. "Ben Fong-Torres." He's holding for you, right now. William takes the phone. The Clerk watches curiously as t kid adopts a new persona.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (deep voice) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a rainy day in San Francisco, Ben Fong-Torres stands i copy-strewn office of the young editor/publisher JANN WEN Several other editors are also present in the background, including David Felton with cigarette-holder in mouth, an prep-school Fact-Checker named ALLISON.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Congratulations. It's gonna be a cover. Neal Preston will shoot 'em next week in L.A. we need you back in San Francisco tomorrow. We'll finish the story here. William is overwhelmed with many emotions, fear topping t list. BEN (cont'd) You can tell the band. Allison, our fact checker, needs you to transmit whatever you have of the story, tonight, now, along with your notes. There is a mojo at the Daily News they'll let us use —

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Mojo?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: A mojo. It's a very modern machine that transmits pages over the telephone. It only takes eighteen Minutes a page...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of feet on pavement. William looks at addresses hustling to the Daily News office. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  126B INT. DAILY NEWS COPY STATION -—- NIGHT 126B William tears pages from his notebook and feeds them into large and clunky earliest model fax machine -- "The Mojo. hear David Bowie. "The Jean Genie." A127 EXT. MAX'S KANSAS CITY -- NIGHT Al27 William weaves, exhausted, into the Stillwater press part this legendary New York nightspot. The Doorman, who check i.d.s, sees the kid and expresses great doubt.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS HOPE
dialogues.text: He's okay, he's with us — Hope shoves him past the Guard, and sends him into a very new world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The famous hub of New York rock and roll. A strong whiff decadence mixes with youthful naivete. Not a hippie in si William walks through, looking for familiar faces. Overhe we hear Stillwater. "If You Say Nothing." The party is fi with scenesters, long silver-haired glamsters, some Briti journalists, and many hunched young skinny bodies in leat jackets. Russell grabs him by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Ah ha! There you are, ya little fucker. Come on ——

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I have some good news.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: -- I'll piss to that. Follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the small bathroom. Russell bolts the door, fa the urinal and pees. His own music throbs in the next roo

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Dennis Hope took me aside, and wants to manage Me solo. Says to lose the band by February. Should I do it? I have no perspective anymore. William pees in silence. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  RUSSELL (cont'd) At what point do I just take the hint? Nobody Loves this band. People like us, do they love us?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (then pissed) Oh —- get this - somebody told Penny Lane I sold her for beer. The network of these chicks! Like I would do that. It's Jeff who told her, right? Not you, right? None of these guys can just calm down and be a fuckin adult. Now she's here, freaking out. Leslie can smell it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (exiting) Wait. I've got something to tell - But he finds himself trailing Russell to the back room ba 128 INT. GIRL'S BATHROOM —- NIGHT - SAME TIME 128 Leslie in the bathroom. Penny enters and watches her discreetly. They stand together, side-by-side at the mirr Leslie looks once, turns and then turns back at Penny. Sh knows. 129 INT. BACKROOM --— NIGHT 129 William sits with the band. Over Jeff's head, Penny hangs nearby, at the outskirts, drinking and dancing. They shar look, feigning casualty.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You guys -—- you guys —-— (beat) You're gonna be on the cover of Rolling Stone. Stunned and overwhelmed, the band waits a beat, lets it s in... and goes wild. Russell, stunned too, looks at the k It's big news. Jeff stands immediately, eyes moist, glass raised.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  (tears welling, instantly) The cover of Rolling Stone. And we made it together. They don't just put somebody with one little hit on the cover of Rolling Stone Fucking Magazine, man. We made it. The band nods solemnly, importantly. JEFF (cont'd) (continuing) Damn it -- I'm gonna enjoy this. The first time I bought that magazine The Beatles were on the cover. Four of them. Four of us. Together.

dialogues.speaker: TOGETHER
dialogues.text: They begin singing the then-current Dr. Hook and the Medi Show hit, "The Cover of the Rolling Stone" to William.

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE
dialogues.text: Who is that girl? She's creeping me out. She's not with any of you, is she?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM/DICK
dialogues.text: She's with me. And now Leslie has confirmation. A symphony of looks, as gets to his feet and moves to confront Penny. Penny Lane' eyes fill and she runs out. Russell stands... and sees Wi also stand. William turns and follows her. Russell stands watching, and does not leave. We hear Elton John's "Mona Lisas and Mad Hatters."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William exits as a crush of Partygoers arrives. He doesn' know where she is. He takes off to examine the cabs stuck traffic. Song continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks in the backs of cabs. None of them her. Music continues. He runs down the streets, looking for he Alone in New York City.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William on the house phone. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily Rugburn, please. 132 INT. HOTEL HALLWAY --— NIGHT 132 William approaches Suite 702. The door is open. He hears band voices, and sees new faces. MUSICIAN # 1 intercepts

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm a friend of Penny Lane's.

dialogues.speaker: MUSICIAN
dialogues.text: Aren't we all - Musician types are leaving.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Where is she? Room Service arrives. Some appetizers and a large expensi bottle of champagne on ice.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM SERVICE GUY
dialogues.text: Can somebody sign for this? William does. ROOM SERVICE GUY (cont'd) Thank you Mr. Rugburn. Two more Musicans (English) exit the back room party. The room is clearing out.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH MUSICIAN
dialogues.text: She's sick. Let's get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH MUSICIAN
dialogues.text: She used to be so much more together. William watches all, champagne in hand, and finds her in backroom. She's addled and nearly passed out.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY LANE
dialogues.text: I'm not good at goodbyes. She sags. He grabs the phone. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  PENNY LANE (cont'd) You're the last of my old-time friends. Polexia went to England with Deep Purple... can you believe that? Even Sapphire's out someplace else. All she left was her quaaludes.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh -- wonderful. (into phone) Front desk? Please send a doctor. Room... what room? 703. 702. Both rooms, either room. This is Mr. Rugburn, Yes. My wife's had an accident with some quaaludes. Yes - I'll do that. The room has emptied out. Just them, and the remnants of movable party that has moved elsewhere. WILLIAM (cont'd) Wake up! He struggles to get her on her feet. She tips over on her strappy platform shoes. He struggles to untie them. 133 EXT. GRADUATION -— DAY 133 The School band plays "Colour My World." School PRINCIPAL the podium.

dialogues.text: Victor Sanchez! Warm applause for another student who grabs his diploma. takes off his mortar board to flash an American flag band He raises his diploma in victory. 136 INT. HOTEL ROOM —- NIGHT 136 Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca William holds Penny Lane, and keeps her moving. It's a s messy slow dance.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: "In the unlikely event of a water landing... "

Remember this, twenty years from now, when we all own home computers and we all travel in shiny electrical cars that move swiftly, high above the city... (beat) They key to the future is keeping today alive forever. Elaine's head lowers slowly in a sea of happy parents. Th day will never end. Mrs. Deegan slips into the seat next her.

dialogues.text: you will be required to..." (gives up) I'm tired. She is very groggy, as he holds her.

Because you don't appear to be related to the famous Rugburns of Rhode Island. His eyes flick to the champagne. The kid takes a hint, re over to the champagne.

He guides her to the ticket counter. Penny wears her green coat, large sunglasses. He sorts through her ma partial tickets. They are both so tired. She shakes off h coat -- she's suddenly very hot -- and he grabs it and lo it through her bags. She's irritable, and ready to go hom 143 INT. AIRPORT GATE — MORNING 143

dialogues.text: (baring her soul) Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  When I was 14, my Mom and her boyfriend took me to a Rolling Stones concert — and I freaked out and I rushed up to the front of the stage and then a thousand people had the same idea at the same time and I was getting crushed. And I couldn't breathe and that thought flashed through me - almost like a car accident - I thought I might die. And it was in the middle of "Midnight Rambler" and Keith Richards saw me. And he came over, and came to the front of the stage, and he pulled me out. And they took me backstage and they gave me coke with ice and a - anda lemon. And I never went home.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What about your Mom?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: She always said - "Marry Up." Marry someone grand. That's why she named me Lady.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Lady Goodman.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You never really get used to it, either.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well -- this -- this just explains everything. He wishes it did. She rubs her stomach. It's a rocky morn WILLIAM (cont'd) See you back in the real world.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: See you back there. She kisses his forehead, and takes off down the accordian Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca leading to her plane. She drops her coat again, bending to retrieve it.

dialogues.text: Hey Lady! Four Woman turn, but not Penny. She disappears. 144 INT. AIRPLANE — DAY 144 Penny Lane settles into her seat on the airplane. She not William watching from the terminal window, and waves.

dialogues.text: Please extinguish all flammable items, and return all seats and tray tables to their full and upright locked positions. She mouths along with the words. AIRPORT TERMINAL -— DAY 145 William walks alongside her plane, moving from terminal w to terminal window. Catching her glance again, he's picki up steam. What's she saying? 146 INT. PLANE — DAY 146 She keeps watching as he runs alongside, still keeping up her plane. She now fully remembers, and places her outstr fingers on the window. She mouths the words: I'll see you back home!

dialogues.text: He us running through her fingers.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM

dialogues.text: 147 INT. BAND PLANE —-— DAY 147 Russell and William are in mid-interview. The kid's micro Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca is out. It's a little bit of a rough flight. William wea the same clothes.

dialogues.text: Why didn't you come back to the party? Bob Dylan showed up. He was sitting at our table for... had to be an hour, right? Just Rapping. Bob Dylan! I kept looking for you. I was going to introduce you. The kid feels pain.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What happened to you last night?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: It's a log story. A sharp jolt of turbulence. Russell begins pounding on th card table in rhythm.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (singing Buddy Holly) "Peggy Sure... Peggy Sue...

dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: "Pretty pretty pretty pretty Peggy Sue... " A moment of laughter, and then bam. Jeff's drink rises an suspends briefly in mid-air. The plane takes another migh knock.

dialogues.text: Doris, we miss you! Fear is creeping in around the edges. William, already an uneasy flier, looks down.

We're gonna do our best Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  to getcha out of this. The rocking of the plane worsens, as all buckle up.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (strapping in for a roller coaster) Rock and roll. The sky darkens abruptly. William looks up, increasingly nervous, stares straight ahead. The plane suddenly drops stabilizes. Everyone is silent but Russell. RUSSELL (cont'd) Wooooco0o Baby! A moment later, an ashen-faced CO-PILOT emerges, balancin himself with hands on the ceiling of the shuddering plane

dialogues.speaker: CO-PILOT
dialogues.text: We're gonna try to land in Tupelo. We're going to have to cut the inside lighting for the next several minutes. We found a field to land in. The kid notices Silent Ed is rubbing a small crucifix.

dialogues.text: A field?

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I can't breathe. Push in on Russell. We hear a series of unfamiliar electr sounds. The plane screwballs through the sky.

dialogues.speaker: CO-PILOT
dialogues.text: It might be a rough set-down. We should be fine. (cracking at the edges) But what we do say in a situation like this is - We would pass but before the plane ... disassembled. However, God help us, if there's anything you want to say to each other, any secrets, anything like that, now would be a good time. But just hang in there. We'll get you out of this. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca He returns to the cockpit. The weather worsens, as the h suddenly pelts the plane, and it comes down hard. Inside shut off. William stares straight ahead, as the cockpit d swings open - total chaos visible inside - and then shuts

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: And everyone thinks it's so glamorous out here.

dialogues.text: (oddly detached) He just told us we're gonna die.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (insecurities running wild) We're gonna crash in Elvis' hometown —-

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: C'mon Dennis, get us a better city. Nervous laughter. Another sheet of hail hits the plane.

dialogues.text: Oh my God.

dialogues.speaker: PUSH IN ON WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Just shaking. Nearly in tears. Hyperventilating.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: If something should happen. I love all of you. I don't think we have to do the secrets thing. The plane shakes. Now lightening strikes very close. A flashing wall of electricity rolls through the plane and evaporates with a burning smell still in the air. In the darkness:

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS HOPE
dialogues.text: I once hit a man in Dearborn, Michigan. A hit-and-run. I hit him and kept on going. I don't know if he's alive or Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  dead, but I'm sorry.

dialogues.text: (gripped with fear) Oh my God. The plane wildly rises, and falls. It stops for a moment. strange smooth patch.

dialogues.text: I love you all too, and you're my family. Especially since Marna left me. But if I ever took an extra dollar or two, here and there, it was because I knew I'd earned it.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (the truth) I don't love you, man. I never did.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Please. Enough.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: NONE of us love you. You act above Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  us. You ALWAYS HAVE!!

dialogues.text: You just held it over us, like you light leave... like we're lucky to be with you. And we had to live with it. I had to live with you, and now I might die with you and it's not fucking fair. William watches, catatonic.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (to Larry and Ed) You hate me? You too? Larry stares at him. Ed says nothing. RUSSELL (cont'd) All this love. All this loyalty. (incredulous, giddy) And you don't even like me.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: And I'm still in love with you Leslie. Bam. The plane is pulling sideways, and dropping altitude

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear anymore. Shut up! Shut up! Shut up!

dialogues.text: (to Jeff) Whatever happens, you're dead.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Don't be self-righteous, Russell, not now. You were sleeping with Penny, that groupie. Last summer, and up until yesterday. Why don't you tell Leslie THAT? Russell tries to get up and attack him. The force keeps h in his seat. He yells. Loud.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: (freaking out) I quit. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  The turbulence worsens. William finds his mouth saying emotional words he cannot control.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: "That groupie?" She was a Band-Aid. All she did was love your band. And you all -- you used her, all of you. You used her and threw her away. She almost died last night, while you were with Bob Dylan. You're always talking about the fans, the fans, the fans. She was your biggest fan and you threw her away. And if you can't see that, that's your biggest problem. Russell and Jeff stare at each other. The plane is rockin very very hard. Leslie is crying.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: I'm gay. They all turn to the silent drummer. (It's his first spok dialogue of the movie.) Then. The plane pops out from below the clouds. Sunshine spikes through the embattled windows of the plane, as they float downwards to the city of Tupelo, Mississippi. A very very uneasy silence fills the plane. No one can look at each o Out bursts the Co-Pilot, giddy with victory.

dialogues.text: Thank God above, WE'RE ALIVE!! WE'RE

TUPELO AIRPORT CORRIDOR -—-— DAY 148 Music continues, as they walk together like ghosts in a l and very pregnant silence, ignoring the kid. Everything i different now. The kid peels off and throws up in a dumps We continue with the band, unhappily moving forward. Will hustles back to catch up. They ignore him. There are much bigger thoughts in play. No one wants to speak.

dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Well, I think we can build on this new honesty. Boom. Russell attacks him, and they're pulled apart. The band continues moving forward, arriving at a fork in the terminals. William stops. This is where he must part comp He stands at the mouth of the next terminal, as the band continues, unaware he's split off. He watches their backs they've forgotten him. Then Russell turns, sensing something missing. William. A now stop and turn. Still shell-shocked, they summon a pre occupied but heartfelt goodbye. William waves. Music continues.

At the end of the aisle, li human finish line, stand Ben Fong-Torres.

dialogues.text: (putting it all together) Oh baby. Ben leads him into the office of Jann Wenner, the editor- publisher. 152 INT. JANN WENNER'S OFFICE -— DAY 152 William sits. Editors are feverishly discussing the next The big concerns of a national magazine are in the air. Everyone is focused and quick. The conversation is machin gun like. Jann Werner turns to the kid.

dialogues.speaker: JANN
dialogues.text: We can't run this piece. The kid's eyes travel to his story -- a stack of fuzzy-lo sheets on the table.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You obviously saw more than you wrote about. After eight days on the road with these guys.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID FELTON
dialogues.text: Didn't anything happen?

dialogues.speaker: JANN
dialogues.text: And where are you in this piece? What did you want to write? Because this reads like what they wanted you to write.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: What happened to your highly-touted think piece on limitations of a middle- level Band in the face of success? William sits speechless. It's sinking in. Failure. Conversation continues at a fast pace:

dialogues.speaker: JANN
dialogues.text: We can push up Chet's Who cover -

dialogues.speaker: FACT CHECKER
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Good 'cause it's going to take me three days to get through this research. It's all handwritten, on little slips. Plus, they all refer to woman as "Chicks." I mean, as a woman I have a problem with that. I know it's a side issue.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID FELTON
dialogues.text: (sympathetic, loquacious) It's a "puff piece." you fell for ‘em. It happens. A relationship forms. You want them to like you. (wistful, chewing cigarette holder) Happened with me and Charlie Manson. He was a very charming... lively... charismatic... Felton catches himself swooning. The other are staring at him. He snaps out of it. DAVID FELTON (cont'd) mass—murderer.

dialogues.text: Please let me finish it. Give me tonight to work on it.

He takes a bite of a candy bar, a sip coffee. He looks at the phone. INT. LESTER BANGS' BEDROOM -—- NIGHT Crazy jazz is playing. Lester Bangs on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER BANGS
dialogues.text: Aw, man. You made friends with them! See, friendship is the booze they feed you. They want you to get drunk on feeling like you belong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. ROLLING STONE --— NIGHT William in the empty Rolling Stone office.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (ruefully) Well, it was fun.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER BANGS
dialogues.text: They make you feel cool. And hey. I met you. You are not "cool."

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I know. Even when I though I was, I knew I wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER BANGS
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  That's because we are uncool! And while women will always be a problem for guys like us, most of the great art in the world is about that very problem. Good-looking people have no spine! Their art never lasts! They get the girls, but we're smarter.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I can really see that now.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER BANGS
dialogues.text: Yeah, great art is about conflict and pain and guilt and longing and love disguised as sex, and sex disguised as love... and let's face it, you got a big head start.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I'm glad you were home.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER BANGS
dialogues.text: I'm always home! I'm uncool!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Me too!

dialogues.speaker: LESTER BANGS
dialogues.text: (leveling) The only true currency in this bankrupt world if what we share with someone else when we're uncool.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (distraught) I feel better

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: My advice to you. I know you think those guys are your friends. You want to be a true friend to them? William takes a deep breath. Looks at the research casset notebooks. The empty page.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER BANGS
dialogues.text: Be honest and unmerciful. (beat) You're doing great. Call me later is you want. I'm always up. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  154 INT. dialogues.text: (reads aloud) "I am flying high over Tupelo, Mississippi, with America's hottest band, and we are all about to die."

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: It. All. He's using it all. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.text: (still back at "Golden God") I didn't say "Golden God." Or did I?

dialogues.text: We never took him seriously, and now it's serious.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: I liked him as a person.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: He was never a "person!" He was a Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  journalist! Russell nods. He looks at Silent Ed, drumming soundlessly a rubber pad.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: You. You had the right idea all along. Ed silently nods thanks.
