dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: It's all in there. But don't worry, it's all unspecific who say what. No names are mentioned in the more embarrassing sequences, it's just completely obvious who's who! We're fucked! Silence.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: I forgot he was there.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS HOPE
dialogues.text: Well, they haven't talked to Russell - he can always deny the key stuff to the fact checker. Then they can't print it.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: (brightening) Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS HOPE
dialogues.text: It's war, my friend. If you'd met me earlier, he would have never been on the around. Dennis hands Russell the phone. DENNIS HOPE (cont'd) He'll live. 156 INT. ROLLING STONE OFFICES -— DAY 156 William is still being congratulated by his new peers. We him woozy but beaming, as Allison the Fact Checker comes Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca of her office, waving the manuscript. She works her way the cluster of editors.

dialogues.speaker: FACT CHECKER
dialogues.text: The band just denied 90% of the story. It's a fabrication. Everyone looks at William, who is speechless and confused Their congratulations stop on a dime. The fact checker ca resist twisting the knife a little. FACT CHECKER (cont'd) You weren't honest. And worse, you wasted our time.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Did you talk to Russell?

dialogues.speaker: FACT CHECKER
dialogues.text: Russell Hammond is the one who denied it.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (darkly) Crazy.

dialogues.speaker: FACT CHECKER
dialogues.text: (one last shot, to William) We're going with the Who - ! The kid has been sandbagged. The machine of a big-time ma whirs into action on another story, as the cluster moves the hall.

dialogues.speaker: SOMEONE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: He's just some fan... what did you expect? William sits there, as only David Felton stay behind, brandishing his cigarette-holder. He sits down next to th kid.

dialogues.speaker: FELTON
dialogues.text: Well, I believe you. He looks at the kid, decides to offer a personal parable. FELTON (cont'd) Jim Morrison once came to my house and drank a beer. The beer is still on my mantle. I'm 35 years old with Jim Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Morrison's beer as a shrine. I wanted to be Earnest Hemingway. Instead. I have Jim Morrison's beer. (shrugs, he's learned to live with it) If you didn't make your story up, good for you. If you did make it up... good for you. The kid looks at him, too tired and still in shock. FELTON (cont'd) Say something, so I know you're alive.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Goodbye. He exits.

dialogues.speaker: FELTON
dialogues.text: Powerful word. Strong. Final. 157 INT. BACKSTAGE CREW MEAL — NIGHT 157 Russell Hammond sits down on a plastic chair with a paper filled with buffet-style food - steak and baked potato. Preoccupied, and several seats away from other crew membe He drinks a glass of milk. Out old friend Sapphire takes seat next to him, holding a skimpy paper plate of vegetab

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: I feel bad.

dialogues.speaker: SAPPHIRE
dialogues.text: Well, at least you feel. That puts you in a higher class of asshole. They eat in silence. Sapphire looks around. The new breed groupies eye her, as they cruise Russell on the periphery They're bolder, flashier. She eyes them back with seniori

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: What did I do?

dialogues.speaker: SAPPHIRE
dialogues.text: Well - you can do what the big boys do. (he looks at her) Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Yeah. The girls still circle Russell nearby. He's unaware.

dialogues.speaker: SAPPHIRE
dialogues.text: You believe these new girls? None of ‘em take birth control, and they eat all the steak. She looks sadly at her plate of vegetables. An ever-sharp mind in last night's clothes, she commands Russell's resp SAPPHIRE (cont'd) They don't even know what it id to be a fan! To blindly love some silly piece of music... or some band so much that it hurts... please, they're all just after the money. Shoo -—- (in their direction) Go rob a bank! It's more honest!

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Is Penny okay?

dialogues.speaker: SAPPHIRE
dialogues.text: The Quaalude Incident. Yeah, it wasn't pretty. She could have died. I always warned her about letting too many guys fall in love with her. I guess I was wrong. (shrugs) On of 'em saved her life. Russell nods.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Well, it's finally over with Leslie. I'm going to call her.

dialogues.speaker: SAPPHIRE
dialogues.text: Let her retire. (he doesn't respond) You want to lock her up in a house in Michigan? Please. (he doesn't respond) Write her a song someday. She deserves it. Something about that girl brought out the best in a lot of... (looks around backstage) pretty average people. She deserves it... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Russell stares into his crew meal, nodding a little. SAPPHIRE (cont'd) (forward thinking) because something tells me twenty years from now, we'll remember her... and not much else. Russell smiles to himself, knows it's true. Dick passes, placing hands on Russell's shoulders, massaging a little.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Have a good vacation. I hope the band stays together. Before it all went down the shitter, it was starting to get really good. Dick claps Russell on the back, and moves on. He turns to Sapphire.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: I'm not going to blame myself. I do make people happy. They just shouldn't get to know me... 'cause it appears to spoil everything.

dialogues.speaker: SAPPHIRE
dialogues.text: Don't be so easy on yourself.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: What gives you the right to get this personal with me.

dialogues.speaker: SAPPHIRE
dialogues.text: Let's not reminisce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William moves like a zombie through the airport, and coll in a seat. He sits still in the crowded flow of human tra A cluster of Flight Attendants pass. One stops, a stylish woman wearing a tall bubble-shaped PSA hat with swirling

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: William? He looks at her. He feels like he's on Mars, and she look like a Martian. ANITA (cont'd) Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  You guys this is my brother!

dialogues.speaker: MALE FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: (ad if meeting a celebrity) "The Narc?!" William looks woefully at them, like a dog who's been hit car.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: You guys, I'll deadhead back later. I think I'm needed.

dialogues.speaker: MALE FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Nice to finally meet you.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: You have a good day! Anita looks in her brother's face.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: You look awful, but that's great. You're living your life! You're finally free of... her.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: Hey. I'll take off work. Let's have an adventure together. You and me, finally. Anywhere you want to go. Anywhere in the world. 159 EXT. WILLIAM'S HOME —- DAY 159 William whistles the family whistle. Sister and brother t up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: This is not my idea of a good time.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Just get me to my bed.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: (resigned) I'll deal with her. William whistles again. Mom meets them at the door. She l Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca at her trashed son who has finally come home. For the fi time, she hugs Anita first, and it's not lost on Anita. It's a clumsy neck-hug, neither wanting to commit. The ki passes to his Mother's left, with suitcase, intentionally nudging her into his sister. Anita takes this as an aggre act of love, and hugs her mother back. Tears stream down face. Their cheeks touch. Mom pulls away, and sees her ow tears on Anita's face. Thinking that she's also crying, s grabs a tissue for them both. 160 INT. ELAINE'S HOUSE --— CONTINUOUS 160 The kid stands in the hallway listening, shaking his head poised to enter his room, unseen by them.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: (so worried) What are we going to do about him?

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: I don't know. Whatever happened to him, I just wish it could have happened to me.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: The magazine killed his story. Now they really hug, Anita gulping back real tears. Willi watches them bonding over the oddest thing - his failure. William goes into the bedroom, the final three feet to sl and shuts the door. A hand places a hotel sign on the doo DO NOT DISTURB. Slight push in.

dialogues.speaker: ON BED
dialogues.text: He collapses with all his clothes on, almost instantly as walls, just as he left them, boast a pantheon of rock her with a very lonely Abraham Lincoln (or Atticus Finch) in 161 INT. ROLLING STONE OFFICES -—-— DAY 161 The elevator doors ding open, and out walks Russell Hammo The Secretary has just finished answering the phone, "Str Arrow Publishers." She puts the caller on hold.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Russel Hammond.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: You're here regarding? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My life. 162 INT. EDITORIAL OFFICE — DAY 162 Russell stands with the editors, observing the fine portr on the walls. He's behind enemy lines, and he knows it. Everything in the room fascinates him.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: I don't care what happens. I don't care if you put us on the cover. But you sent us a kid and... and he was a fan. And we all made friends with him - absolutely, to get a good story. But then we actually liked him. We thought he's... show us our lives in some mythic way and I guess... we're not mythic. We panicked.

dialogues.speaker: JANN
dialogues.text: You denied most of the story.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, here's the problem with the truth. It's too true —

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Well, we appreciate the visit. The last time an artist came here, it was Buddy Miles and he punched me.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: I'm not punching anybody. I am personally, as of 2 pm yesterday, ona voyage of self-reinvention. This is about William Miller. (counting off fingers) He lives with us, he lost his virginity, he saw us at our worst, appreciated our best, he saved two lives, including mine... he smuggled about a half-pound of pot into Boston, and we never even told him - Nearby, David Felton looks at another editor, raising an eyebrow. RUSSELL (cont'd) -- we told him too much, we told him everything... He almost died with us Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  over Tupelo... if the band survives him, it'll be a miracle... but you know, he tried to keep up, and that's a journalist to me.

dialogues.speaker: JANN
dialogues.text: It's too late. We're going with a different cover.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: (immediately) Thank God. But Russell looks around at the numerous portraits if dea legendary rock stars, fixing on the one photo closest to them, a very vulnerable-looking Janis Joplin. A second th RUSSELL (cont'd) You tell me it's too late. But I could go back to my hotel room and... and O.D. tonight and something tells me you'd find a way to put me on the cover of the next issue. Am I right? He looks at their faces. They cannot disagree. RUSSELL (cont'd) I'm learning the game. (beat, shrug) We fucked up. We made friends with him.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Next time we'll all be more professional.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Maybe so. (beat, an odd thought) But God forbid, the day comes when selling yourself is as important as the music you make. (rueful, to Hendrix on the wall) You might have died at the right time, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: JANN
dialogues.text: Thank you for visiting. Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Do what you want, but the story is Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at the entrance. Raises his hand. RUSSELL (cont'd) Good evening! 162A EXT. SAN FRANCISCO — DAY 162A Russell stands outside, a traveling man with no where to Oddly, and in a way that surprises him, the world begins speak to him again... little noises everywhere, turning i music of its own. It's a beautiful and compelling "silenc He thrusts his hands deep in his pockets, and takes a bre of life. His head filling again with the music of the wor he begins to walk down the street. Very naturally, and qu randomly, he is noticed by young passersby. They can't he it. He looks like a star. They can't quite figure out who is, but it's someone, and they begin to follow him down t street. Unbeknownst to him as he walks along, deep in tho a small crowd begins to form... following him. 163 INT. BREAKFAST TABLE — DAY 163 A quiet kitchen. Anita has been cooking. A substantial breakfast has been placed on the table. Sausage, orange juice... and now Anita sets down a plate of pancakes, wit syrup and butter, in front of her mother. William watches mother facing an old enemy - white sugar.

dialogues.speaker: ANITA
dialogues.text: They're called pancakes. Who knows when we'll be together again. Splurge. It's what most people call breakfast. Mom looks at her children, and takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: I went through your records. And I found a song to play for you. She goes to the stereo and puts on a record. The two chil eye each other - what's coming next? (Song to be chosen) The two kids eye each other again. Self-consciously avoid their gaze, Mom sits and toys with her breakfast. It's a she clearly wants them to hear. It's a song from the hear They look at her, amazed. Elaine looks up, regards her fa Somehow they're back at this table. They continue eating breakfast. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: ON SIDEWALK 164
dialogues.text: Bam. A bundle of bound Rolling Stone Magazines lands on t newsstand pavement with a thud. Someone reaches in to cut cord, as the magazines puff up into view. It's the new is with Russell Hammond on the cover. The title: Stillwater Deep. Just another stack of magazines waiting to be place the racks.
